editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Old Batchelour, A COMEDY. As it is ACTED at the Theatre Royal, BY Their MAJESTIES Servants.

q.l: Quem tulit ad Scenam ventoso gloria Curru,
Sic leve, sic parvum est, animum quod laudis avarum

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Peter Buck, at the Sign of the Temple near the Temple-gate in Fleet-street, 1693.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, Charles Lord Clifford of Lanesborough, &c.
div.p: IT is with a great deal of Pleasure, that I lay hold on this first Occasion, which, the Accidents of my Life have given me of writing to your Lordship: For since at the same time I write to all the World, it will be a means of publishing, (what I would have every Body know) the Respect and Duty which I owe and pay to you. I have so much Inclination to be yours, that I need no other Engagement: But the particular Ties, by which I am bound to your Lordship and Family, have put it out of my power to make you any Complement; since all Offers of my self, will amount to no more than an honest Acknowledgment, and only shew a willingness in me to be grateful.

I am very near wishing, That it were not so much my Interest to be your Lordships Servant, that it might be more my Merit; not that I would avoid being obliged to you, but I would have my own Choice to run me into the Debt; that I might have it to boast, I had distinguished a Man, to whom I would be glad to be obliged, even without the hopes of having it in my Power, ever to make him a return.

It is impossible for me to come near your Lordship, in any kind, and not to receive some Favour; and while in appearance I am only making an Acknowledgment (with the usual underhand dealing of the World) I am at the same time, insinuating my own Interest. I cannot give your Lordship your due, without tacking a Bill of my own Priviledges. 'Tis true, if a Man never committed a Folly, he would never stand in need of a Protection: But then Power would have nothing to do, and good Nature no occasion to shew it self; and where those Vertues are, 'tis pity they should want Objects to shine upon. I must confess this is no reason, why a Man should do an idle thing, nor indeed any good Excuse for it, when done; yet it reconciles the uses of such Authority and Goodness, to the necessities of our Follies; and is a sort of Poetical Logick, which, at this time I would make use of, to argue your Lordship into a Protection of this Play. It is the first
Offence I have committed in this kind, or indeed, in any kind of Poetry, tho' not the first made publick; and, therefore, I hope will the more easily be pardoned: But had it been Acted, when it was first written, more might have been said in its behalf; Ignorance of the Town and Stage, would then, have been Excuses in a young Writer, which now, almost four Years experience, will scarce allow of. Yet I must declare my self sensible of the good Nature of the Town, in receiving this Play so kindly, with all its Faults, which I must own were, for the most part, very industriously covered by the care of the Players; for, I think, scarce a Character but receiv'd all the Advantage it would admit of, from the justness of Action.

As for the Criticks, my Lord, I have nothing to say, to, or against any of them of any kind; from those who make just Exceptions, to those who find fault in the wrong place. I will only make this general Answer in behalf of my Play (an Answer, which Epictetus advises every Man to make for himself, to his Censurers) viz. That if they who find some Faults in it were as intimate with it as I am, they would find a great many more. This is a Confession, which I need not to have made; but however, I can draw this use from it, to my own Advantage, that I think there are no Faults in it, but what I do know; which, as I take it, is the first step to an amendment.
Thus I may live in hopes (sometime or other) of making the Town amends; but you, my Lord, I never can, tho' I am ever

closer.signed: Your Lordships most obedient and most humble Servant, Will. Congreve.

div.head: To Mr. CONGREVE.
div.l: WHEN Vertue in pursuit of Fame appears,
And forward shoots the growth beyond the Years:
We timely court the rising Hero's Cause;
And on his side, the Poet wisely draws;
Bespeaking him hereafter, by Applause.
The days will come, when we shall all receive,
Returning Interest from what now we give:
Instructed, and supported by that Praise,
And Reputation, which we strive to raise.
Nature so coy, so hardly to be Woo'd
Flies, like a Mistress, but to be pursu'd.
O CONGREVE! boldly follow on the Chase;
She looks behind, and wants thy strong Embrace:
She yields, she yields, surrenders all her Charms,
Do you but force her gently to your Arms:
Such Nerves, such Graces, in your Lines appear,
As you were made to be her Ravisher.
DRYDEN has long extended his Command,
By Right divine, quite through the Muses Land,
Absolute Lord; and holding now from none,
But great Apollo, his undoubted Crown:
(That Empire settled, and grown old in Pow'r)
Can wish for nothing, but a Successor:
Not to enlarge his Limits, but maintain
Those Provinces, which he alone could gain.
His eldest Wicherly, in wise Retreat,
Thought it not worth his quiet to be great.
Loose, wandring, Etherege, in wild Pleasures lost,
And foreign Int'rests, to his hopes long lost:
Poor Lee and Otway dead! CONGREVE appears,
The Darling, and last Comfort of his Years:
May'st thou live long in thy great Masters smiles,
And growing under him, adorn these Isles:
But whenâ€”when part of him (be that but late)
His Body yielding must submit to Fate,
Leaving his deathless Works, and thee behind,
(The natural Successor of his Mind)
Then may'st thou finish what he has begun:
Heir to his Merit, be in Fame his Son.
What thou hast done, shews all is in thy Power;
And to Write better, only must Write more.
'Tis something to be willing to commend;
But my best Praise, is, that I am your Friend.

div.head: To Mr. CONGREVE.
div.l: THe Danger's great in these censorious days,
When Criticks are so rife, to venture Praise:
When the infectious and ill-natured Brood
Behold, and damn the Work, because 'tis good;
And with a proud, ungenerous Spight would try
To pass an Ostrocism on Poetry.
But you, my Friend, your Worth does safely bear
Above their Spleen; you have no cause for fear;
Like a well-metled Hawk, you took your flight
Quite out of reach, and almost out of sight.
As the strong Sun, in a fair Summers day,
You rise, and drive the Mists and Clowds away,
The Owls and Bats, and all the Birds of Prey.
Each Line of yours, like polisht Steel's so hard,
In Beauty safe, it wants no other guard.
Nature her self's beholden to your Dress,
Which tho' still like, much fairer you express.
Some vainly striving Honour to obtain,
Leave to their Heirs the Traffick of their Brain;
Like China under Ground, the ripening Ware,
In a long time, perhaps grows worth our Care:
But you now reap the Fame, so well you've sown;
The Planter tasts his Fruit to ripeness grown.
As a fair Orange-tree at once is seen,
Big with what's ripe, yet springing still with Green:
So at one time, my worthy Friend appears,
With all the sap of Youth, and weight of Years.
Accept my pious Love, as forward Zeal,
Which tho' it ruins me I can't conceal:
Expos'd to Censure for my weak Applause,
I'm pleas'd to suffer in so just a Cause:
And tho' my Offering may unworthy prove,
Take as a Friend the Wishes of my Love.

div.head: To Mr. CONGREVE, on his PLAY, called, The OLD BATCHELOR.
div.l: WIT, like true Gold, refin'd from all Allay,
Immortal is, and never can decay:
'Tis in all Times and Languages the same;
Nor can an ill Translation quench the Flame:
For, tho' the Form and Fashion don't remain,
Th' intrinsick value still it will retain.
Then let each studied Scene be writ with Art;
And Iudgment sweat to form the labour'd Part:
Each Character be just, and Nature seem;
Without th' Ingredient, Wit, 'tis all but Phlegm:
For that's the Soul, which all the Mass must move,
And wake our Passions into Grief, or Love.
But you, too Bounteous, sow your Wit so thick,
We are surpriz'd, and know not where to pick:
And while our Clapping does you Iustice do,
Our selves we injure, and lose something new.
What may'nt we then, great Youth, of thee presage,
Whose Art and Wit so much transcend thy Age?
How wilt thou shine at thy Meridian height?
Who, at thy rising, give so vast a Light.
VVhen DRYDEN dying, shall the VVorld deceive,
VVhom we Immortal, as his VVorks, believe;
Thou shalt succeed, the Glory of the Stage,
Adorn and entertain the coming Age.

div.head: PROLOGVE intended for the old Btcahelour, sent to the Author, by an unknown Hand.
div.l: MOST Authors on the Stage at first appear
Like Widows-Bridegrooms, full of doubt and fear:
They judge from the experience of the Dame,
How hard a Task it is to quench her Flame:
And who falls short of furnishing a course,
Up to his brawny Predecessors force;
With utmost rage from her Embraces thrown,
Remains convicted, as an empty Drone.
Thus often, to his Shame, a pert Beginner
Proves in the end, a miserable Sinner.
As for our Youngster, I am apt to doubt him,
With all the vigour of his Youth about him:
But he, more Sanguine, trusts in one and twenty,
And impudently hopes he shall content you:
For tho' his Batchelour be worn and cold:
He thinks the Young may club to help the Old:
And what alone can be atchieved by neither,
Is often brought about by both together.
The briskest of you all have felt Allarms,
Finding the fair One prostitute her Charms
With broken Sighs, in her old Fumblers Arms.
But for our Spark, he Swears he'll ne're be jealous
Of any Rivals, but young lusty Fellows.
Faith let him try his Chance, and if the Slave,
After his bragging, prove a washy Knave;
May he be banish'd to some lonely Den,
And never more have leave to dip his Pen:
But if he be the Champion he pretends,
Both Sexes sure will join to be his Friends;
For all agree, where all can have their ends.
And you must own him for a Man of Might,
If he holds out to please you the third Night.

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.l: HOW this vile World is chang'd! In former days,
Prologues, were serious Speeches, before Plays;
Grave solemn Things, as Graces are to Feasts;
Where, Poets beg'd a Blessing, from their Guests.
But now, no more like Suppliants, we come;
A Play makes War, and Prologue is the Drum:
Arm'd with keen Satyr, and with pointed Wit,
We threaten you who do for Iudges sit,
To save our Plays, or else we'll damn your Pit.
But for your Comfort, it falls out to day,
We've a young Author and his first born Play;
So, standing only on his good Behaviour,
He's very civil, and entreats your Favour.
Not but the Man has Malice, would he show it,
But on my Conscience he's a bashful Poet;
You think that strangeâ€”no matter, he'll out grow it.
Well, I'm his Advocateâ€”by me he prays you,
(I don't know whether I shall speak to please you)
He praysâ€”O bless me! what shall I do now!
Hang me if I know what he prays, or how!
And 'twas the prettiest Prologue, as he wrote it!
Well, the Deuce take me, if I hau'e forgot it.
O Lord, for Heavens sake excuse the Play,
Because, you know, if it be damn'd to day,
I shall be hang'd for wanting what to say.
How my sake thenâ€”but I'm in such Confusion,
I cannot stay to hear your Resolution.

list.label: Men,
Heartwell, a furly old Batchelour, pretending to slight Women; secretly in Love with Silvia,
Bellmour, in Love with Belinda,
Vainlove, capricious in his Love; in Love with Araminta,
Sharper,
Sir Joseph Wittol,
Capt. Bluffe,
Fondlewife, a Banker,
Setter, a Pimp,
Servant to Fondlewife.
Women,
Araminta, in Love with Vainlove,
Belinda, her Cousin and affected Lady, in Love with Bellmour,
Laetitia, Wife to Fondlewife,
Silvia, Vainlove's forsaken Mistress,
Lucy, her Maid,
Betty.

div.head: SCENE I. The Street.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: VAinlove, and abroad so early! good Morrow; I thought a Contemplative Lover could no more have parted with his Bed in a Morning, than a' could' have slept in't.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Bellmour, good Morrowâ€”Why truth on't is, these early Sallies are not usual to me; but Bussiness as you see Sirâ€” Shewing Letters. And Business must be follow'd, or be lost.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox o' Businessâ€”And so must Time, my Friend, be close pursued, or lost. Business is the rub of Life, perverts our Aim, casts off the Blas, and leaves us wide and short of the intended Mark:

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Pleasure, I guess you mean.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, what else has meaning?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Oh the Wise will tell youâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: More than they believeâ€”Or understand.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: How how, Ned, a wise Man say more than he understands?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Ay ay, pox Wisdom's nothing but a pretending to know and believe more than really we do. You read of but one wise Man, and all that he knew was, that he knew nothing. Come come, leave Business to Idlets, and Wisdom to Fools; they have need of 'em: Wit, be my
Faculty; and Pleasure, my Occupation; and let Father Time shake his Glass. Let low and earthy Souls grovel till they have work'd themselves six foot deep into a Graveâ€”Business is not my Elementâ€”I rowl in a higher Orb and dwellâ€”.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: In Castles ith' Air of thy own building: That's thy Element Nedâ€”Well as high as a Flyer as you are, I have a Lure may make you stoop. Flings a Letter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I marry Sir, I have a Hawks Eye at a Womans handâ€”There's more Elegancy in the false Spelling of this Superscription Takes up the Letter. than in all Ciceroâ€”Let me seeâ€”How now! Dear persidious Vainlove. Reads.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Hold hold, 'slife that's the wrong.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay let's see the Name (Silvia!) how can'st thou be ungrateful to 'that Creature? She's extreamly pretty and loves thee intirelyâ€”I have heard her breath such Raptures about theeâ€”

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay, or any Body that she's aboutâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No faith Frank you wrong her; she has been just to you.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: That's pleasant, by my troth from thee, who hast enjoy'd her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Neverâ€”Her Affections, 'tis true by Heaven, she own'd it to my Face; and blushing like the Virgin Morn when it disclosed the Cheat, which, that trusty Bawd of Nature, Night, had hid, confess'd her Soul was true to you; tho' I by treachery had stoll'n the Blissâ€”

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: So was true as Turtleâ€”An imagination Ned, ha? Preach this Doctrin to Husbands, and the married Women will adore thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why faith I think it will do well enoughâ€”If the Husband be out of the way, for the Wife to shew her Fondness and Impatience of his Absence, by choosing a Lover as like him as she can, and what is unlike she may help out with her own Fancy.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: But is it not an Abuse to the Lover to be made a Blind of? For she only stalks under him to take aim at her Husband.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As you say the Abuse is to the Lover, not the Husband: For 'tis an Argument of her great Zeal towards him, that she will enjoy him in Essigie.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: It must be a very superstitious Country, where such Zeal passes for true Devotion. I doubt it will be damn'd by all our Protestant Husbands for slat Idolatryâ€”But if you can make Alderman Fondlewife of your Perswasion, this Letter will be needless.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, the old Banker with the handsome Wife?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let me see, Laetitia! Oh 'tis a delicious Morsel. Dear Frank thou art the truest Friend in the World.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p:
Ay, am I not? To be continually starting of Hares for you to Course. We were certainly cut out for one another; for my Temper quits an
Amour, just where thine takes it upâ€”But read that, it is an Appointment for me, this Evening; when Fondlewife will be gone out of Town, to meet the Master of a Ship about the return of a Venture which he's in danger of losing. Read, read.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Reads. Hum, Humâ€”Out of Town this Evening, and talks of sending for Mr. Spintext to keep me Company; but I'le take care, he shall not be at home. Good! Spintext! Oh the Fanatick one-ey'd Parson!

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Reads. Hum, Humâ€”That your Conversation will be much more agreeable, if you can counterfeit his Habit to blind the Servants. Very good! Then I must be disguishedâ€”With all my Heartâ€”It adds a Gusto to an Amour; gives it the greater resemblance of Theft; and among us lewd Mortals, the deeper the Sin the sweeter. Frank I'm amaz'd at thy good Natureâ€”

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Faith I hate Love when 'tis sorced upon a Man; as I do Wineâ€”And this Business is none of my seeking; I only hapned to be once or twice, where, Laetitia was the handsomest Woman in Company, so consequently apply'd my self to herâ€”And it seems she has taken me at my wordâ€”Had you been there or any Body 'thad been the same.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wish I may succeed as the same.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Never doubt it; for if the Spirit of Cuckoldom be once raised up in a Woman, the Devil can't lay it, till she has dont.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee, what sort of Fellow is Fondlewife?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: A kind of Mungril Zealot, sometimes very precise and peevish: But I have seen him pleasant enough in his way; much addicted to Jealousie, but more to Fondness: So that as he is often Jealous without a Cause, he's as often satisfied without Reason.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A very even Temper and sit for my purpose. I must get your Man Setter to provide my Disguise.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay, you may take him for good and-all if you will, for you have made him sit for no Body elseâ€”Wellâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your'e going to visit in return of Silvia's Letterâ€”Poor Rogue. Any hour of the day or night will serve herâ€”But do you know nothing of a new Rival there?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Yes, Heartwell, that furly, old, pretended Woman-hater thinks her Vertuous; that's one reason why I fail her: I would have her fret her self out of conceit with me, that she may entertain some Thoughts of him. I know he visits her ev'ry day.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yet rails on still, and thinks his Love unknown to us; a little time will swell him so, he must be forc'd to give it birth, and the discovery must needs be very pleasant from himself, to see what pains he will take, and how he will strein to be deliver'd of a Secret, when he has miscarried on't already.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Well good Morrow, let's dine together, I'l meet at the old place.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With all my Heart, it lies convenient for us, to pay our Afternoon Service to our Mistresses; I find I am damnably in Love; I'm so uneasie for not seeing Belinda yesterday.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: But I saw my Araminta, yet am as impatient. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why what a Cormorant in Love am I! who not contented with the slavery of honourable Love in one place, and the pleasure of enjoying some half a score Mistresses of my own acquiring; must yet take Vainlove's Business upon my hands, because it lay too heavy upon his: So am not only forc'd to lie with other Mens Wives for 'em, but must also undertake the harder Task, of obliging their Mistressesâ€”I must take up, or I shall never hold out; Flesh and Blood cannot bear it always.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I'm sorry to see this, Ned: Once a Man comes to his Soliloques I give him for gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sharper, I'm glad to see thee.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What, is Belinda cruel, that you are so thoughtful?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No faith, not for thatâ€” But there's a Business of Consequence fall'n out to day that requires some Consideration.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Prithee what mighty Business of Consequence canst thou have?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you must know, 'tis a piece of Work toward the finishing of an Alderman; it seems I must put the last hand to it, and dub him Cuckold, that he may be of equal Dignity with the rest of his Brethren. So I must beg Belinda's Pardonâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Faith e'en give her over for good-and-all; you can have no hopes of getting her for a Mistress, and she is too Proud, too Inconstant, too Affected and too Witty, and too handsome for a Wise.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But she can't have too much Monyâ€”There's twelve thousand Pound Tomâ€”'Tis true she is excessively foppish and affected, but in my Conscience I believe the Baggage loves me, for she never speaks well of me her self, nor suffers any Body else to rail at me. Then as I told you there's twelve thousand Poundâ€”Humâ€”Why faith upon second Thoughts, she does not appear to be so very affected neitherâ€”Give her her due, I think the Woman's a Woman, and that's all. As such I'm sure I shall like her; for the Devil take me if I don't love all the Sex.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And here comes one who Swears as heartily he hates all the Sex.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Who Heartwell! Ay, but he knows better thingsâ€”How now George, where hast thou been snarling odious Truths, and entertaining
company like a Physician, with discourse of their diseases and infirmities? What fine Lady hast thou been putting out of conceit with her self, and perswading that the Face she had been making all the morning wos none of her own? for I know thou art as unmannerly and as unwelcome to a Woman, as a Looking-glass after the Small-pox.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I confess I have not been sneering fulsome Lies and nauseous Flattery, fawning upon a little tawdry Whore, that will fawn upon me again, and entertain any Puppy that comes; like a Tumbler with the same tricks over and over. For such I guess may have been your late employment.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Would thou hadst come a little sooner, Vainlove would have wrought thy Conversion and been a Champion for the Cause.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What, has he been here? that's one of Loves April-fools, is always upon some errand that's to no purpose, ever embarking in Adventures, yet never comes to harbour.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Tha's because he always sets out in foul Weather, loves to buffet with the Winds, meet the Tide and sail in the Teeth of opposition.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What has he not drop't Anchor at Araminta?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Truth on't is she sits his temper best, is a kind of floating Island; sometimes seems in reach, then vanishes and keeps him busied in the search.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: She had need have a good share of sense, to manage so Capricious a Lover.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith I don't know, he's of a temper the most easie to himself in the World; he takes as much always of an Amour as he cares for, and quits it when it grows stale, or unpleasant.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: An argument of very little Passion, very good Understanding, and very ill Nature.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And proves that Vainlove plays the Pool with Discretion.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: You Bellmour are bound in gratitude to stickle for him; you with pleasure reap that fruit, which he takes pains to sow: he does the drudgery in the Mine, and you stamp your image on the Gold.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's of another opinion, and says I do the drudgery in the Mine; well, we have each our share of sport, and each that which he likes best; 'tis his diversion to Set, 'tis mine to Cover the Partridge.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And it should be mine to let 'em go again.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Not till you had Mouth'd a little George, I think that's all thou art fit for now.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Good Mr. Young-fellow, your mistaken; as able as your self and as nimble too, though I mayn't have so much Mercury in my Limbs; 'tis true indeed, I don't force Appetite, but wait the natural call of my Lust, and think it time enough! to be lew'd, after I have had the temptation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Time enough, ay too soon, I should rather have expected, from a person of your gravity.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Yet it is oftentimes too late with some of you young, termagant flashy sinnersâ€”you have all the guilt of the intention, and none of the pleasure of the practiceâ€”'tis true you are so eager in pursuit of the temptation, that you save the Devil the trouble of leading you into it: Nor is it out of discretion, that you don't swallow that very Hook your selves have baited, but you are cloy'd with the preparative, and what you mean for a Whet, turns the edge of your puny Stomacks. Your love is like your courage, which you shew for the first year or two upon all occasions; till in a little time, being disabled or disarm'd, you abate of your vigor; and that daring Blade which was so often drawn, is bound to the Peace for ever after.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou art an old Fornicator of a singular good principle indeed! and art for encouraging Youth, that they may be as wicked as thou art at thy years.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I am for having every body be what they pretend to be; a Whoremaster be a Whoremaster; and not like Vainlove, kiss a Lap-Dog with passion, when it would disgust him from the Ladies own Lips.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That only happens sometimes, where the Dog has the sweeter Breath, for the more cleanly conveyance. But George, you must not quarrel with little Gallantries of this nature; Women are often won by 'em: who would refuse to kiss a Lap-Dog, if it were preliminary to the Lips of his Lady?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Or omit playing with her Fan; and cooling her if she were hot, when it might entitle him to the office of warming her when she should be cold?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What is it to read a Play in a rainy day, when it may be the means of getting into a fair Ladies Books? Though you should be now and then interrupted in a witty Scene, and she perhaps preserve her Laughter, till the jest were over; even this may be born with, considering the reward in prospect.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I confess you that are Womens Asses bear greater burdens, are forced to undergo Dressing, Dancing, Singing, Sighing, Whining, Rhyming, Flattering, Lying, Grinning, Cringing, and the drudgery of loving to boot.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O Brute, the drudgery of loving!

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ay, why to come to Love through all these in cumbrances is like coming to an Estate overcharg'd with Debts, which by the time you have pay'd, yields no further profit than what the bare tillage and manuring of the Land will produce at the expence of your own Sweat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee how dost thou love?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: He! he hates the Sex.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: So I hate Physick tooâ€”yet I may love to take it for my health.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well come off George, if at any time you should be taken straying.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: He has need of such an excuse, considering the present state of his Body.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: How d'ee mean?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Why if whoring be purging (as you call it) then I may say Marriage is entring into a Course of Physick.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How George, do's the Wind blow there?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: It will as soon blow North and by Southâ€”marry quotha! I hope in Heaven I have a greater portion of Grace, and I think I have baited too many of those Traps, to be caught in one my self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who the Devil would have thee? unless 'twere an Oyster-woman, to propagate young Fry for Bilingsgate â€” thy Talent will never recommend thee to any thing of better quallity.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: My Tallent is chiefly that of speaking truth, which I don't expect should ever recommend me to People of Quality â€” I thank Heaven, I have very honestly purchas'd the hatred of all the great Families in Town.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And you in return of Spleen hate them: But could you hope to be receiv'd into the Alliance of a noble Familyâ€”

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No, I hope I shall never merit that affliction â€”to be punish'd with a Wife of Birthâ€”be a Stag of the first Head and bear my Horns aloft, like one of the supporters of my Wives Coat. S'death I would not be a Cuckold to ere an illustrious Whore in England.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What not to make your santily Man! and provide for your Children!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: For her Children you mean.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ay there you've nick't itâ€” there's the Devil upon Devilâ€”Oh the Pride and Joy of Heart 'twould be to me, to have my Son and heir resemble such a Dukeâ€”to have a sleering Coxcomb scoff and cry, Mrâ–ª your Son's mighty like his Grace, has just his smile and air of's Face. Then replies anotherâ€”me think he has more of the Marquess of such a place, about his Nose and Eyes; though a' has my Lord what d'ee-cals Mouth too a Titleâ€”Then I to put it off as unconcern'd, come chuck the Infant under the chin, force a smile and cry, ay, the Boy takes after his. Mothers relationsâ€”when the Devil and she knows, 'tis a little Compound of the whole Body of Nobility.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well but George I have one Question to ask youâ€”

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Pox I have pratled away my timeâ€”I hope you are in no hast: for an Answerâ€”for I shan't stay now. Looking on his Watch.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay prithee Georgeâ€”

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No, besides my Business, I see a Fool coming this way. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do's he mean? Oh here he comes, stand close let 'em pass.

div.stage: Sir Ioseph Wittall and Capt. Bluffe, cross the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What in the name of wonder is it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: 'Tis a tawdry Outside.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And a very beggarly Liningâ€”yet he may be worth your acquaintanceâ€”a little of thy Chymistry Tom, may extract Gold from that Dirt.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Say you so? faith I am as poor as a Chymist and would be as industrious. But what was he that follow'd him? is not he a Draggon that watches those Golden Pippins?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hang him, no, he a Draggon! if he be 'tis a very peacefull one, I can ensure his Anger dormant; or should he seem to rouse, 'tis but well lashing him, and he will sleep like a Top.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ay, Is he of that kidney?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yet is ador'd by that Biggot Sr. Ioseph Wittoll, as the image of of Valour: He calls him his Back, and indeed they are never asunderâ€”yet last night, I know not by what mischance, the Knight was alone, and had fallen into the hands of some Nightwalkers, who I suppose would have pillag'd him: But I chanc'd to come by and rescued him, though I believe he was heartily frightned, for as soon as ever he was loose, he ran away, without staying to see who help'd him.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Is that Bully of his in the Army?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, But is a pretender, and wears the habit of a Soldier, which now a'days as often cloaks Cowardice, as a Black Gown does Atheismâ€”You moust know he has been abroadâ€”went purely to run away from a Campagne; enrich'd himself with the plunder of a few Oaths; â€” and here vents 'em against the General, who slighting Men of Merit, and preferring only those of interest, has made him quit the Service.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Wherein no doubt he magnifies his own performance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Speaks Miracles, is the Drum to him own praiseâ€”the only implement of a Soldier he resembles, like that, being full of blustring noise and emptinessâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And like that, of no use but to be beaten.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Right, but then the comparison breaks, for he will take a drubbing with as little noise as a Pulpit Cushion.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: His name, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why that, to pass it current too, he has guilded with a Title; he is call'd, Capt. Bluffe.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, He endeavour his acquaintanceâ€”you steer another Course, are bound,
sp.l: For Love's I stand: I, for the Golden Coast.
May each succeed in what he wishes most.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: SUre that's he and alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Umâ€” Ay this, this is the very damn'd place; the inhumane Cannibals, the bloody-minded Villains would have Butcher'd me last night: No doubt, they would have slead me alive, have fold ray Skin, and devour'd my Members.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How's this!

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: An it hadn't been for a civil Gentleman as came by and frightn'd 'em away â€” but agad I durst not stay to give him thanks.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: This must be Belmour he means â€” ha! I have a thoughtâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Zooks, would the Captain would come; the very remembrance makes me quake; agad I shall never be reconciled to this place heartily.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: 'Tis but trying, and being where I am at worst, now luck !â€”curs'd fortune! this must be the place, this damn'd unlucky placeâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Agad and so 'tisâ€”why here has been more mischief done I perceive.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: No, 'tis gone, 'tis lostâ€”ten thousand Devils on that chance which drew me hither; ay here, just here, this spot to me is Hell; nothing to be found, but the despair of what i've cost.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Poor Gentlemanâ€”by the Lord Harry ile stay no longer, for I have sound tooâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ha! who's that has found? what have you found? restore it quickly, or byâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Not I Sir, not I, as I've a Soul to be sav'd, I have found nothing but what has been to my loss, as I may say, and as you were saying Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: O your Servant Sir. you are safe then it seems; 'tis an ill Wind that blows no body good: well, you may rejoyce over my ill fortune, since it pay'd the price of your ransome.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: I rejoyce! agad not I Sir; I'me sorry for your loss, with all my Heart, Blood and Guts Sir; and if you did but know me, you'd nere say I were so ill natur'd.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Know you! why can you be so ungrateful, to forget me!

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: O Lord forget him! No no Sir, I don't forget youâ€”because I never saw your face before, agad. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sharper.
sp.p: How! Angrily.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Stay, slay Sir, let me recollectâ€”he's a damn'd angry Fellowâ€”I believe I hadâ–ª better remember him, till I can get out of his light; but out o' sight out o' mind agad Aside.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Methought the service I did you last night Sir, in preserving you from those Russians, might have taken better root in your shallow memory.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Gads-Daggers-Belts-Blades-and Scabbards, this is the very Gentleman! how shall I make him a return suitable to the greatness of his meritâ€”I had a pretty thing to that Purpose, if he han't frighted it out of my memory. Hem! hem! Sir, I must submissively implore your pardon for my transgression of ingratitude and omission; having my intire dependance Sir, upon the supersinity of your goodness, which, like an innundation will I hope totally immerge the recollection of my errour, and leave me floating in your sight, upon the full, blown, Bladders of repentanceâ€”by the help of which, I shall once more hope to swim into your favour Bows.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Soâ€”h, O Sir I am easily pacify'd, the acknowledgment of a Gentlemanâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Acknowledgment! Sir I am all over acknowledgment, and will not stick to show it in the greatest extremity, by night, or by day, in sickness, or in health, Winter, or Summer, all Seasons and occasions shall testify the reality and gratitude of you superabundant humble Servant Sir Ioseph Wittoll Knight. Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sir Ioseph Wittoll!

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: The same Sir, of Wittoll-hall in Comitatu Bucks.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Is it possible! Then I am happy to have obliged the Mirrour of Knighthood and Pink of Courtesie in the Age, let me embrace you.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: O Lord Sir!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: My loss, I esteem as a trifle repay'd with interest, since it has purchas'd me the friendship and acquaintance of the person in the World, whose Character I admire.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: You are only pleas'd to say so Sirâ€”But pray if I may be so bold, what is that loss you mention?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: O term it no longer so Sir. In the Scuffle last Night I only dropt a Bill of a hundred Pound, which I confess, I came half despairing to recover; but thanks to my better Fortuneâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: You have found it Sir then it seems; I profess I'me heartily gladâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sir your humble Servantâ€”I don't question but you are; that you have so cheap an opportunity of expressing your gratitude and generosity. Since the refunding so trivial a Sum, will wholly acquit you and doubly engage me.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: What a dickens do's he mean by a trival Sum aside But han't you found it Sir!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: No otherwise I vow to Gad but in my hopes in you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: But that's sufficientâ€”'Twere injustice to doubt the honour of Sir Io. Wittoll.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: O Lord Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: You are above (I'me sure) a thought so low, to suffer me to lose what was ventur'd in your service; Nay 'twas in a mannerâ€”Pay'd down for your deliverance; 'twas so much lent youâ€”And you scorn, 'Ile say that for youâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Nay 'Ile say that for my self (with your leave Sir) I do scorn a dirty thing. But agad 'Ime a little out of pocket at present,

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Pshaw you can't want a hundred Pound. Your Word is sufficient any whereâ–ª 'Tis but borrowing so much Dirt, you have large Acres and can soon repay itâ€”Mony is but Dirt Sir Iosephâ€”Mere Dirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: But I profess, 'tis a Dirt I have wash'd my Hands of at present; I have lay'd it all out upon my Back.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Are you so extravagant in Cloaths Sir Ioseph?

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest I profess, ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest, and I did not know that I had say'd it, and that's a better Jest than tother. 'Tis a sign you and I ha'n't been long acquainted; you have lost a good Jest for want of knowing meâ€”I only mean a Friend of mine whom I call my Back; he sticks as close to me, and follows me through all dangersâ€”he is indeed Back, Breast and Headpiece as it were to me â€”agad he's a brave Fellowâ€”Pauh, I am quite another thing, when I am with him: I don't fear the Devil (God bless us) almost if he be by. Ahâ€” had he been with me last night â€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: If he had Sir, what then? he could have done no more, nor perhaps have suffer'd so muchâ€”had he a hundred Pound to lose Angrily.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: O lord Sir by no means (but I might have sav'd a hundred Pound) I meant innocently as I hope to be sav'd Sir (a damn'd hot Fellow) only as I was saying, I let him have all my ready Mony to redeem his great Sword from Limboâ€”But Sir I have a Letter of Credit to Alderman Fondlewife, as far as two hundred Pound, and this Afternoon you shall see I am a Person, such a one as you would wish to have met with.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: That you are Ile be sworn aside Why that's great and like your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Oh here â€¢â€¢ comes ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ of Troy, welcome my Bully, my Back, â€¢ gad ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: How how, my young Knight? Not for fear I hope, he that knows me must be a stranger to fear.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Nay agad I hate fear ever since I had like to have dy'd of a fright. Butâ€”

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: But? Look you here Boy, here's your antidote, here's your Jesuits Powder for a shaking fitâ€”But who hast thou got with thee, is he of mettle? Laying his Hand upon his Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Ay Bully, a Devilish smart Fellow, 'a will sight like a Cock.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Say you so? then I honour himâ€”But has he been abroad? for every Cock will sight upon his own Dunghil.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: I don't know, but I'le present youâ€”

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: I'le recommend my selfâ€”Sir I honour you; I understand you love Fighting, I reverence a Man that loves Fighting, Sir I Kiss your Hilts.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sir your Servant, but you are misinform'd, for unless it be to serve my particular Friend, as Sir Joseph here, my Country, or my Religion, or in some very Justifiable Cause, I'me not for it.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: O Lord I beg your pardon Sir, I find you are not of my Pallat, you can't relish a Dish of Fighting without Sweet Sawce. Now I thinkâ€”Fighting, for Fighting sake's sufficient Cause; Fighting, to me's Religion and the Laws.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Ah, well said my Hero; was not that great Sir? by the Lord-Harry he says true; Fighting, is Meat, Drink and Cloth to him. But Back, this Gentleman is one of the best Friends I have in the World and saved my Life last Nightâ€”You know I told you.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Ay! Then I honour him againâ€”Sir may I crave your name?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ay Sir, my name's Sharper.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Sharper Embrace my Backâ€”very wellâ€”By the Lord Harry Mr. Sharper he's as brave a Fellow as Cannibal, are not you Bullyâ€”Back?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Hannibal I believe you mean Sir Joseph.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Undoubtedly he did Sir; faith Hannibal was a very pretty Fellow â€”but Sir Joseph, comparisons are odiousâ€”Hannibal was a very pretty Fellow in those Days, it must be grantedâ€”But Alas Sir! were he alive now, he would be nothing, Nothing in the Earth.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How Sir! I make a doubt, if there be at this Day a greater General Breathing.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Oh excuse me Sir; have you serv'd a broad Sir?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Not I really Sir.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Oh I thought soâ€”Why then you can know nothing Sir: I'me afraid you scarce know the History of the Late War in Flanders, with all its particulars.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, no more than publick Letters, or Gazett's tell us.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Gazette! Why there again nowâ€”Why, Sir, there are not three words of Truth, the Year round, put into the Gazetteâ€”I'll tell you a strange thing now as to thatâ€”You must know, Sir, I was resident in Flanders the last Campagn, had a small Post there; but no matter for thatâ€”Perhaps, Sir, there was a scarce any thing of moment done but an humble Servant of yours, that shall be nameless, was an Eye-witness ofâ€”I won't say had the greatest share in't. Tho' I might say that too, since I am no Body you knowâ€”Well, Mr. Sharper, would you think it? In all this timeâ€”as I hope for a Truncheonâ€”this rascally Gazette-writer never so much as once mention'd meâ€”Not once by the Warsâ€”Took no more notice, than as if Nol. Bluffe had not been in the Land of the Living.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Strange!

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Yet by the Lord Harry 'tis true Mr. Sharper, for I went every day to Coffee-houses to read the Gazette my self.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Ay, ay, no matterâ€”You see Mr. Sharper after all I am content to retireâ€”Live a private Personâ€”Scipio and others have done it.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Impudent Rogue. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Ay, this damn'd Modesty of yoursâ€”Agad if he would put in for't he might be made General himself yet.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Oh fy no Sir Iosephâ€”You know I hate this.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Let me but tell Mr. Sharper a little, how you let fire once out of the mouth of a Canonâ€”agad he did; those impenetrable Whiskers of his have confronted Flamesâ€”

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Death, what do you mean Sir Ioseph?

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Look you now, I tell you he's so modest he'l own nothing.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Pish you have put me out, I have forgot what I was about. Pray hold your Tongue, and give me leave. Angrily.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: I am dumb.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: This Sword I think I was telling you of Mr. Sharperâ€”This Sword I'l maintain to be the best Divine, Anatomist, Lawyer or Casuist in Europe; it shall decide a Controversie or split a Causeâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Nay, now I must speak; it will split a Hair by the Lord Harry, I have seen it.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Zoons Sir, it's a Lie, you have not seen it, nor shant see it; Sir I say you can't see; what de'e say to that now?

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: I am blind.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Death, had any other Man interrupted meâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Good Mr. Sharper speak to him; I dare not look that way.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Captain, Sir Ioseph's penitent.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: O I am calm Sir, calm as a discharg'd Culverinâ€”But 'twas indiscreet, when you know what will provoke meâ€”Nay come Sir Ioseph, you know my Heat's soon over.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Well I am a Fool sometimesâ€”But I'm sorry.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Come we'll go take a Glass to drown Animosities. Mr. Sharper will you partake?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I wait on you Sir; nay pray Captainâ€”You are Sir Ioseph's Back. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE Changes to Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Ay! nay Dearâ€”prithee good, dear sweet Cousin no more. Oh Gad, I swear you'd make one sick to hear you.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Bless me! what have I said to move you thus?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Oh you have raved, talked idly, and all in Commendation of that filthy, awkard, two-leg'd Creature, Manâ€”you don't know what you said, your Fever has transported you.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: If Love be the Feeer which you mean; kind Heav'n avert the cure: Let me have Oil to feed that Flame and never let it be extinct, till I my self am Ashes.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: There was a Whineâ€”O Gad I hate your horrid Fancyâ€”This Love is the Devil, and sure to be in Love is to be possess'dâ€”Tis in the Head, the Heart, the Blood, theâ€”All overâ€”O Gad you are quite spoil'dâ€”I shall loath the sight of Mankind for your sake.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Fie, this is gross Affectationâ€”A little of Bellmour's Company would change the Scene.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Filthy Fellow! I wonder Cousinâ€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I wonder Cousin you should imagine, I don't perceive you love him.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O I love your hideous Fancy! Ha, ha, ha, love a Man!

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Love a Man! yes, you would not love a Beast.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Of all Beasts not an Assâ€”Which is so like your Vainloveâ€”Lard I have seen an Ass look so Chagrin, Ha, ha, ha, (you must pardon me I can't help Laughing) that an absolute Lover would have concluded the poor Creature to have had Darts, and Flames, and Altars, and all that in his Breast. Araminta, come I'll talk seriously to you now; could you but see with my Eyes, the buffoonry of one Scene of Address, a Lover, set out with all his Equipage and Appurtenances; O Gad! sure you wouldâ€”But you play the Game, and consequently can't see the Miscarriages obvious to every Stander by.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I can see something near it when you and Bellmour meet. You don't know that you dreamt of Bellmour last Night, and call'd him aloud in your sleep.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Pish, I can't help dreaming of the Devil sometimes; would you from thence infer I love him?

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: But that's not all; you caught me in your Arms when youâ–ª named him, and press'd me to your Bosomâ€”Sure if I had not pinch'd you till you wak'd, you had stisled me with Kisses.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O barbarous Aspersion!

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: No Aspersion, Cousin, we are aloneâ€”Nay, I can tell you more.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: I deny it all.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: What, before you hear it?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: My Denyal is premeditated like your Maliceâ€”Lard, Cousin, you talk odlyâ€”What ever the Matter is, O my Sol, I'm afraid you'l follow evil Courses.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this is pleasant.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: You may laugh, butâ€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: You think the malicious Grinn becomes youâ€”The Devil take Bellmourâ€”Why do you tell me of him?

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Oh is it come outâ€”Now you are angry, I am sure you love him. I tell no Body else Cousinâ€”I have not betray'd you yet.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Prithee tell it all the World, it's false. Betty. Calls.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Come then, Kiss and Friends.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Prithee don't be so Peevish.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Prithee don't be so Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Did your Ladyship, call Madam?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Get my Hoods and Tippet, and bid the Footman call a Chair.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I hope you are not going out in dudgeon, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Madam, there areâ€”

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Is there a Chair?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: No, Madam, there are Mr. Bellmour and Mr. Vainlove to wait upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Are they below?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: No, Madam, they sent before, to know if you were at home.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: The Visit's to you, Cousin, I suppose I am at my liberty.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p:
Be ready to shew 'em up.
Exit Footman. I can't tell, Cousin, I believe we are equally concern'd: But if you continue your Humour, it won't be very entertainingâ€”(I know she'd fain be persuaded to stay. Aside. Belin.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: I shall oblige you, in leaving you to the full and free enjoyment of that Conversation you admire.

div.stage: Enter Betty, with Hoods and Looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Let me see; hold the Glassâ€”Lard I look wretchedly to day.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Betty, why don't you help my Cousin? Putting on her Hoods.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p:
Hold off your Fists, and see that he gets a Chair with a high Roof, or a very low Seatâ€” Stay, Come back here you Mrs. Fidgetâ€”You are so ready to go to the Footmanâ€”Here, take 'em all again, my Mind's chang'd, I won't go.
Exit Betty with the Things.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: So, this I expectedâ€”You won't oblige me then, Cousin, and let me have all the Company to my self?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: No; upon deliberation, I have too much Charity to trust you to your self. The Devil watches all opportunities; and in this favourable disposition of your Mind, Heav'n knows how far you may be tempted: I am tender of your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to youâ€”But who's malicious now, Belinda?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Not I; witness my Heart I stay out of pure Affection.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: In my Conscience I believe you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So Fortune be prais'd! To find you both within, Ladies, isâ€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: No Miracle, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not o' your side, Madam, I confessâ€”But my Tyrant there and I, are two Buckets that can never come together.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Nor are ever likeâ€”Yet we often meet and clash.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How never like! marry Hymen forbid. But this it is to run so extravagantly in Debt; I have laid out such a world of Love in your Service, that you think you can never be able to pay me all: So shun me for the same reason that you would have done.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Ay, on my Conscience, and the most impertinent and troublesome of Dunsâ€”A Dun for Mony will be quiet, when he sees his Debtor has not wherewithalâ€”But a Dun for Love is an eternal Torment that never restsâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Till he has created Love where there was none, and then gets it for his pains. For importunity in Love, like importunity at Court; first creates its own Interest, and then pursues it for the Favour.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Favours that are got by Impudence and Importunity, are like Discoveries from the Rack, when the afflicted Person, for his ease, sometimes confesses Secrets his Heart knows nothing of.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p:
I should rather think Favours, so gain'd, to be due Rewards to
indefatigable Devotionâ€”For as Love is a Deity, he must be serv'd by Prayer.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O Gad, would you would all pray to Love then, and let us alone.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: You are the Temples of Love, and 'tis through you, our Devotion must be convey'd.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Rather poor silly Idols of your own making, which, upon the least displeasure you forsake, and set up newâ€”Every Man, now, changes his Mistress and his Religion, as his Humour varies or his Interest.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: O Madamâ€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Nay come, I find we are growing serious, and then we are in great danger of being dullâ€”If my Musicke master be not gone, I'll entertain you with a new Song, which comes pretty near my own Opinion of Love and your Sexâ€”Who's there? Calls.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Only to the next door, Madam; I'll call him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, you wont hear me with Patience.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: What's the Matter, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, onlyâ€”

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy Tongueâ€”Lard, he has so pester'd me with Flames and Stuffâ€”I think I shan't endure the sight of a Fire this Twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yet all can't melt that cruel frozen Heart.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O Gad I hate your hideous Fancyâ€”You said that once beforeâ€”If you must talk impertinently, for Heav'ns sake let it be with variety; don't come always, like the Devil, wrapt in Flamesâ€”I'll not hear a Sentence more, that begins with an, I burnâ€”Or an, I beseech you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But tell me how you would be Ador'dâ€”I am very tractable.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Then know, I would be Ador'd in Silence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Humph, I thought so, that you might have all the Talk to your selfâ€”You had better let me speak, for if my Thoughts fly to any pitch, I shall make villainous Signs.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: What will you get by that? To make such Signs as I won't understand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, but if I'm Tongue-ty'd, I must have all my Actions free toâ€”Quicken your Apprehensionâ€”And I-gad let me tell you, my standing Argument is depress'd in dumb shew.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: O I am glad we shall have a Song to divert the Discourseâ€”Pray oblige us with the last new Song.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Thus, to a ripe, consenting Maid,
Poor, old, repenting Delia said,
Would you long preserve your Lover?
Would you still his Goddess reign?
Never let him all discover,
Never let him much obtain.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Men will admire, adore and die,
While wishing at your Feet they lie:
But admitting their Embraces,
Wakes 'em from the golden Dream;
Nothing's new besides our Faces,
Every Woman is the same.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: So, how de'e like the Song, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O very well perform'dâ€”But I don't much admire the Words.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I expected itâ€”there's too much Truth in 'em: If Mr. Gavot will walk with us in the Garden, we'll have it once againâ€”You may like it better at second hearing. You'l bring my Cousin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I dare not speak to her, but I'll make Signs.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O fogh, your dumb Rhetorick is more ridiculous, than your talking Impertinence; as an Ape is a much more troublesome Animal than a Parrot.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Ay, Cousin, and 'tis a sign the Creatures mimick Nature well, for there are few Men, but do more silly things, than they say.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Well, I find my Apishness has paid the Ransome for my Speech, and set it at libertyâ€”Tho', I confess, I could be well enough pleas'd to drive on a Love-bargain, in that silent mannerâ€”'Twould save a Man a World of Lying and Swearing at the Years end. Besides, I have had a little Experience, that brings to my mindâ€”
When Wit and Reason, both, have fail'd to move;
Kind Looks and Actions (from Success) do prove,
Ev'n Silence may be Eloquent in Love.

div.head: SCENE I. The Street.

sp.speaker: Silvia.
sp.p: WILL a' not come then?

sp.speaker: Lucy,
sp.p: Yes Yes, come, I warrant him, if you will go in and be ready to receive him.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Why did you not tell me?â€”Whom mean you?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Whom you should mean, Heartwell.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Senseless Creature, I meant my Vainlove.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You may as soon hope, to recover your own Maidenhead, as his Love. Therefore e'n set your Heart at rest, and in the name of opportunity mind your own Business. Strike, Heartwell home, before the Bait's worn off the Hook, Age will come; he nibbled fairly yesterday, and no doubt will be eager enough to day, to swallow the Temptation.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Well, since there's no remedyâ€”Yet tell meâ€”For I would know, though to the anguish of my Soul; how did he refuse? Tell meâ€”how did he receive my Letter, in Anger or in Scorn?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Neither; but what was ten times worse, with damn'd, senseless indifference. By this Light I could have spit in his Faceâ€”Receive it! why he receiv'd it, as I would one of your Lovers that should come emptyhanded; as a Court Lord does his Mercers Bill, or a begging Dedication; â€”a' receiv'd it, as if 'thad been a Letter from his Wife.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: What did he not read it?

sp.speaker: Lcuy.
sp.p: Hum'd it over, gave you his Respects, and said, he would take time to peruse itâ€”But then he was in haste.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Respects, and peruse it! He's gone, and Araminta has bewitch'd him from meâ€”Oh, how the name of Rival fires my Bloodâ€”I could curse 'em both; eternal Jealousie attend her Love; and Disappointment, meet his Lust. Oh that I could revenge the Torment he has caus'dâ€”Methinks I feel the Woman strong within me, and Vengeance itches in the room of Love.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I have that in my Head may make Mischief.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: How, dear Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You know Aramintas dissembled Coyness has won, and keeps him hersâ€”

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Could we perswade him, that she Loves anotherâ€”

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, you're out; could we perswade him, that she doats on him, himselfâ€”Contrive a kind Letter as from her, 'twould disgust his nicely, and take away his Stomach.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Impossible, 'twill never take.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Trouble not your Head. Let me aloneâ€”I will inform my self of what past between 'em to Day, and about it streightâ€”Hold, I'me mistaken, or that's Heartwell, who stands talking at the Cornerâ€”'tis heâ€”Go get you in Madam, receive him pleasantly, dress up your Face in Innocence and Smiles; and dissemble the very want of Dissimulationâ€”You know what will take him.

sp.speaker: Salv.
sp.p: 'Tis as hard to Counterfeit Love, as it is to conceal it: but I'le do my weak endeavour, though I fear I have not Art.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Hang Art, Madam, and trust to Nature for Dissembling.
sp.l: Man, was by Nature Womans Cully made:
We, never are but by our selves betray'd.

div.stage: Enter Heartwell, Vainlove and Bellmour following.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hist hist, is not that Heartwell going to Silvia?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: He's talking to himself, I think; Prithee lets try if we can hear him

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why whither in the Devils name am I going now? Humâ€”Let me thinkâ€”Is not this Silvia's House, the Cave of that Enchantress and which consequently I ought to shun as I would infection? To enter here, is to put on the envenom'd Shirt, to run into the Embraces of a Faver, and in some raving fit, be led to plunge my self into that more Consuming Fire, a Womans Arms. Ha! well recollected, I will recover my reason and be gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now Venus forbid!

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Hustâ€”

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Well, Why do you not move? Feet do your Officeâ€”Not one Inch; no, Foregod I'me caughtâ€”There stands my North, and thither my Needle pointsâ€”Now could I curse my self, yet cannot repent. O thou Delicious, Damn'd, Dear, destructive Woman! S'death how the young Fellows will hoot me! I shall be the Jest of the Town: Nay in two Days, I expect to be Chronicled in Ditty, and sung in woful Ballad, to the Tune of the Superanuated Maidens Comfort, or the Batchelors Fall; and upon the third, I shall be hang'd in Effigie, pasted up for the exemplary Ornament of necessary Houses and Coblers S'tallsâ€”Death, I can't think outâ€”He run into the danger to loose the apprehension. Goes in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A very certain remedy, probatum estâ€”Ha, ha, ha, poor George, thou art it'h right, thou hast sold thy self to Laughter; the ill-natur'd Town will find the Jest just where thou hast lost it. Ha, ha, how a' strugled, like an Old Lawyer, between two Fees.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Or a young Wench, betwixt pleasure and reputation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Or as you did to day, when half afraid you snatch'd a kiss from Araminta.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: She has made a quarrel on't.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pauh, Women are only angry at such offences, to have the pleasure of forgiving 'em.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: And I love to have the pleasure of making my peaceâ€”I should not esteem a Pardon if too easie won.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou dost not know what thou would'st be at; whether thou wouldst have her angry or pleas'd. Couldst thou be content to marry Araminta?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Could you be content to go to Heaven?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hum, not immediately, in my conscience not heartily? I'de do a little more good in my generation first, in order to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Nor I to marry Araminta till I merit her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But how the Devil dost thou expect to get her if she never yield?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: That's true; but I wouldâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Marry her without her Consent; thour't a Riddle beyond Woman.â€”

div.p: Trusty Setter what tidings? How goes the project?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: As a lew'd projects do Sir, where the Devil prevents our endeavours with success.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A good hearing, Setter.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Well, I'le leave you with your Engineer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And hast thou provided necessaries?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: All, all Sir; the large sanctified Hat, and the little precise Band, with a swinging long Spiritual Cloak, to Cover Carnal Knaveryâ€” not forgetting the Black Patch, which Tribulation Spintext wears as I'm inform'd, upon one Eye, as a penal Mourning for the ogling Offences of his Youth; and some say, with that Eye, he first discover'd the frailty of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well in this Fanatick Fathers habit, will I confess Latitia.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Rather pepare her for Confession, Sir by helping her to Sin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be at your Masters Lodging in the Eveningâ€”I shall use the Robes.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I shall Sirâ€”I wonder to which of these two Gentlemen I do most properly appertainâ€”The one uses me as his Attendant; the other (being the better acquainted with my parts) employs me as a Pimp: why that's much the more honourable employmentâ€”by all meansâ€”I follow one as my Master, but the tother follows me as his Conductor.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ther's the Hang-Dog his Manâ€”I had a power over him in the Reign of my Mistress; but he is too true a Valet-de-chambre not to affect his Masters faults; and consequently is revolted from his Allegiance.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Undoubtedly 'tis impossible to be a Pimp and not a Man of parts. That is without being politick, diligent, secret, wary and soforthâ€”And to all this valiant as Herculesâ€”That is, passively valiant and actively obedient. Ah! Setter what a treasure is here lost for want of being known.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Here's some Villany a Foot lies so thoughtful; may be I, may discover something in my Masqueâ€”Worthy Sir, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Why if I were known, I might come to be a great Man.â€”

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Not to intempt your meditation.â€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: And I should not be the first that has procur'd his greatness by Pimping.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Now Poverty and the Pox light upon thee, for a Contemplative Pimp.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Ha! what art, who thus maliciously hast awakned me, from my Dream of Glory? speak thou vile Disturberâ€”

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Of thy most vile Cogitationsâ€”Thou poor, Conceited Wretch, how, wer't thou valuing thy self, upon thy Masters employment. For he's the head Pimp to Mr. Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Good Words, Damsel, or I shallâ€”But how dost thou know my Master or me?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, I know both Master and Man to be.â€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: To be Men perhaps; nay faith like enough; I often march in the rear of my Master, and enter the Breaches which he was made.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, the Breach of Faith, which he has begun: Thou Traytor to thy lawful Princess.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Why how now! prithee who art? lay by that Worldly Face and produce your natural Vizor.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No Sirrah, I'le keep it on to abuse thee and leave thee without hopes of revenge.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Oh! I begin to smoak ye, thou art some forsaken Abigail, we have dallied with heretoforeâ€”And art come to tickle thy Imagaination with remembrance of inicuity past.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No thou pitiful Flatterer of thy Masters imperfections; thou Maukin made up of the Shreds and Pairings of his superfluous Fopperies.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Thou art thy Mistresses foul self, Composed of her fully'd iniquities and Cloathing.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Hang theeâ€”Beggars Currâ€”Thy Master is but a Mumper in Love, lies Canting at the gate; but never dare presume to enter the House.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Thou art the Wicket to thy Mistresses Gate; to be opened for all Comers. In Fine thou art the high Road to thy Mistress, as a Clap is to the Pox.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Beast, filthy Toad, I can hold no longer, look and tremble. Vmasques.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: How, Mrs. Lucy!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wonder thou hast the impudence to look me in the Face.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Adsbud who's in fault, Mistress Mine? who slung the first Stone? who undervalued my Function? and who the Devil could know you by instinct?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You could know my Office by instinct, an behang'd, which you have slander'd most abominably. It vexes me not what you said of my Person; but that my innocent Calling should be expos'd and scandaliz'dâ€”I cannot bear it. Cries.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Nay faith Lucy I'me sorry, I'le own my self to blame, though we were both in fault as to our Officesâ€”Come I'le make you any reparation.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Swear.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I do swear to the utmost of my power.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: To be brief then; what is the reason your Master did not appear to Day according to the Summons I brought him?

sp.speaker: Set.
sp.p: To answer you as brieflyâ€”He has a cause to be try'd in another Court.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Come tell me in plain Terms, how forward he is with Araminta.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Too forward to be turn'd backâ€”Though he's a little in disgrace at present about a Kiss which he forced. You and I can Kiss Lucy without all that.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Stand offâ€”He's a precious Jewel.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: And therefore you'd have him to set in your Ladies Locket.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: He'l be in the Piaza presently.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Remember to Days behaviourâ€”Let me see you with a penitent Face.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: What no Token of amity Lucy? you and I don't use to part with dry Lips.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No no, avauntâ€”I'le not be slabber'd and kiss'd nowâ€”I'me not 'ith humour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I'le not quit you soâ€”I'le Follow and put you into the humour.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: And so out of your unwonted Generosity.â€”

sp.speaker: Sr. Jo.
sp.p: And good Nature, Back; I am good Natur'd and I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: You have given him a note upon Fumblewife for a hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Sr. Jo.
sp.p: Ay ay, poor, Fellow, he ventur'd fair fort.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: You have disoblig'd me in itâ€”for I have occasion for the Mony, and if you would look me in the Face again and live, go, and force him, to redeliver you the Noteâ€”goâ€”and bring it me hither. I'le stay here for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: You may stay till the day of Judgment then, by the Lord Harry. I know better things than to be run through the Guts for a hundred Poundâ€”Why I gave that hundred Pound for being saved, and d' â€¢ e think, an there were no danger, I'le be so ungrateful to take it from the Gentleman again?

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p:
Well, go to him from meâ€”Tell him, I say, he must refundâ€”
or Bilbo's the Word, and Slaughter will ensueâ€”If he refuse, tell himâ€”But whisper thatâ€”Tell himâ€”I'll pink his Soulâ€”but whisper that softly to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: So softly, that he shall never hear on't I warrant youâ€”Why what a Devil's the Matter, Bully, are you mad? Or de'e think I'm mad? Agad for my part, I don't love to be the Messenger of ill News; 'tis an ungrateful Officeâ€”So tell him your self.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: By these Hilts I believe he frightned you into this Composition; I believe you gave it him out of fear, pure paultry fearâ€”confess.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: No, no, hang't I was not afraid neitherâ€”Tho' I confess he did in a manner snap me upâ€”Yet I can't say that it was altogether out of fear, but partly to prevent mischiefâ€”For he was a devilish cholerick Fellow: And if my Choller had been up too, agad there would have been mischief done, that's flat. And yet I believe if you had been by, I would as soon have let him a' had a hundred of my Teeth. Adheart if he should come just now when I'm angry, I'd tell himâ€”Mum.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou'rt a lucky Rogue; there's your Benefactor, you ought to return him Thanks now you have receiv'd the Favour.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sir Iosephâ€”Your Note was accepted, and the Mony paid at sight: I'm come to return my Thanksâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: They won't be accepted, so readily as the Bill, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I doubt the Knight repents, Tomâ€”He looks like the Knight of the sorrowful Face.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: This is a double Generosityâ€”Do me a Kindness and refuse my Thanksâ€”But I hope you are not offended that I offer'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: May be I am Sir, may be I am not Sir, may be I am both Sir; what then? I hope I may be offended, without any offence to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Hey day! Captain, what's the matter? You can tell.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Mr. Sharper, the matter is plainâ€”Sir Ioseph has found out your Trick, and does not care to be put upon; being a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Trick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Ay Trick, Sir, and won't be put upon Sir, being a Man of Honour Sir, and so Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Hearkee, Sir Joseph, a word with yeâ€”In consideration of some favours lately receiv'd; I would not have you draw your self into a Premunire, by trusting to that sign of a Man thereâ€”That Pot gun charg'd with Wind.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, Captain, come justifie your selfâ€”I'll give him the Lie if you'll stand to it.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Nay then I'l be beforehand with you, take thatâ€”Oafe. Cuffs him. Bluff.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Captain, will you see this? Won't you pink his Soul?

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Husht, 'tis not so convenient nowâ€”I shall find a time.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What do you mutter about a time, Rascalâ€”You were the Incendiaryâ€”There's to put you in mind of your timeâ€”A Memorandum. Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: O this is your time Sir, you had best make use on't.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I Gad and so I will: There's again for you. Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: You are obliging Sir, but this is too publick a Place to thank you in: But in your Ear, you are to be seen again.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ay thou inimitable Coward and to be feltâ€”As for Example.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, prithee come away, 'tis scandalous to kick this Puppy without a Man were cold, and had no other way to get himself a heat.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Yery wellâ€”Very fineâ€”But 'tis no matterâ€”Is not this fine, sir Joseph?

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Indifferent, agad in my opinion very indifferentâ€”I'd rather go plain all my Life, than wear such Finery.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Death and Hell to be affronted thus! I'l die before I'l suffer it. draws.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: O Lord his Anger was not raised beforeâ€”Nay, dear Captain, don't be in Passion now, he's goneâ€”Put up, put up, dear Back, 'tis your Sir Ioseph begs, come let me kiss thee, so so, put up, put up.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: By Heav'n 'tis not to be put up.

sp.speaker: Sir. Io.
sp.p: What, Bully? Bluff. Th' Affront.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: No agad no more, 'tis for that's put up already; thy Sword I mean.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: Well, Sir Ioseph, at your entreatyâ€”But were not you my Friend; Abus'd and Cuff'd and Kick'd. Putting up his Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: Ay, ay, so were you too; no matter, 'tis past.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: By the immortal Thunder of great Guns, 'tis falseâ€”He sucks not vital Air who dares affirm it to this Face. Looks big.

sp.speaker: Sir Io.
sp.p: To that Face I grant you Captainâ€”No, no, I grant youâ€”Not to that Face by the Lord Harryâ€”If you had put on your fighting Face before, you had done his Businessâ€”He durst as soon have kiss'd you, as kick'd you to your Faceâ€”But a Man can no more help what's done behind his Back, than what's saidâ€”Come wee'l think no more of what's past.

sp.speaker: Bluff.
sp.p: I'll call a Council of War within to consider of my Revenge to come. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE Changes to Silvia's Lodgings.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: As Amoret and Thyrsis, lay
Melting the Hours, in gentle Play;
Ioining Faces, mingling Kisses,
And exchanging harmless Blisses:
He trembling, cry'd, with eager haste,
O let me feed as well as taste,
I die, if I'm not wholly blest.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The fearful Nymph reply'dâ€”Forbear;
I cannot, dare not, must not hear:
Dearest Thyrsis, do not move me,
Do notâ€”do notâ€”if you Love me
O let meâ€”still the Shepherd said;
But while she fond Resistance made,
The hasty Joy, in strugling sled.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Vex'd at the Pleasure she had miss'd,
She frown'd and blush'd, then sigh'd and kiss'd,
And seem'd to moan, in sullen Cooing,
The sad miscarriage of their Wooing:
But vain alas! were all her Charms;
For Thyrsis deaf to Loves allarms,
Bassled and senseless, tir'd her Arms.

div.stage: After the Song, a Dance of Anticks.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Indeed it is very fineâ€”I could look upon 'em all day.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Well, has this prevail'd for me, and will you look upon me?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: If you could Sing and Dance so, I should love to look upon you too.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why 'twas I Sung and Danc'd; I gave Musick to the Voice, and Lise to their Measuresâ€”Look you here Silvia, here are Songs and Dances, Poetry and Musickâ€”hark! how Pulling out a Purse and chinking it. sweetly one Guinea rhymes to anotherâ€”And how they dance to the Musick of their own Chink. This buys all the 'totherâ€”And this thou shalt have; this, and all that I am worth for the purchase of thy Loveâ€”Say, is it mine then, ha? Speak Syrenâ€”Oons why do I look on her! Yet I mustâ€”Speak dear Angel, Devil, Saint, Witch; do not rack me in suspence.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Nay don't stare at me soâ€”You make me blushâ€”I cannot look.

sp.speaker: Heart.
