sp.p: Oh Manhood, where art thou! What am I come to? A Womans Toy; at these years! Death, a bearded Baby for a Girl to dandle. O dotage, dotage! That ever that noble passion, Lust, should ebb to this degreeâ€”No reslux of vigorous Blood: But milky Love, supplies the empty Channels; and prompts me to the softness of a Childâ€”A meer Infant and would suck. Can you love me Silvia? speak.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: I dare not speak till I believe you, and indeed I'm afraid to believe you yet.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Pox, how her Innocence torments and pleases me! Lying, Child, is indeed the Art of Love; and Men are generally Masters in it: But I'm so newly entred, you cannot distruit me of any skill in the treacherous Mysteryâ€”Now by my Soul, I cannot lie, though it were to serve a Friend or gain a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Must you lie then, if you say you Love me?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No, no, dear Ignorance, thou beauteous Changel'ngâ€”I tell thee I do love thee, and tell it for a Truth, a naked Truth, which I'm ashamed to discover.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: But Love, they say, is a tender thing, that will smooth Frowns, and make calm an angry Face; will soften a rugged Temper, and make ill-humoured People good: You look ready to fright one, and talk as if your Passion were not Love, but Anger.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: 'Tis both; for I am angry with my self, when I am pleased with youâ€”And a Pox upon me for loving thee so swellâ€”Yet I must onâ€”'Tis a bearded Arrow, and will more easily be thrust forward than drawn back.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Indeed if I were well assur'd you lov'd; but how can I be well assur'd?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Take the Symptomsâ€”And ask all the Tyrants of thy Sex, if their Fools are not known by this Party-coloured Liveryâ€”I am Melancholy when thou art absent; look like an Ass when thou art present; Wake for you, when I should Sleep, and even Dream of you, when I am Awake; Sigh much, Drink little, Eat less, court Solitude, am grown very entertaining to my self, and (as I am informed) very troublesome to everybody else. If this be not Love, it is Madness, and then it is pardonableâ€”Nay yet a more certain Sign than all this; I give thee my Mony.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Ay, but that is no Sign, for they say, Gentlemen will give Mony to any naughty Woman to come to Bed to themâ€”O Gemini, I hope you don't mean soâ€”For I won't be a Whore.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: The more is the pity. Aside.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Nay if you would Marry me, you should not come to Bed to meâ€”You have such a Beard and would so prickle one. But do you intend to Marry me?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: That a Fool should ask such a malicious Question! Death, I shall be drawn in, before I know where I amâ€”However, I find I am pretty sure of her consent, if I am put to it. Aside. Marry you? no, no, I'll love you.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Nay, but if you love me, you must Marry me; what dont I know my Father lov'd my Mother, and was married to her?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in old days People married where they lov'd; but that fashion is chang'd, Child.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Never tell me that, I know it is not chang'd by my self; for I love you, and would Marry you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I'll have my Beard shav'd, it shan't hurt thee, and we'l go to Bedâ€”

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: No, no, I'm not such a Fool neither bat I can keep my selfâ€”honestâ€”Here, I won't keep any thing that's yours, I hate you now, Throws the Purse. and I'll never see you again, 'cause you'd have me be naught. Going.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Damn her let her go, and a good riddanceâ€”Yet so much Tenderness and Beautyâ€”and Honesty together is a Jewelâ€”Stay Silviaâ€”But then to Marryâ€”Why every Man plays the Fool once in his Life: But to Marry, is playing the Fool all ones Life long.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: What did you call me for?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I'll give thee all I have: And thou shalt live with me in every thing, so like my Wife, the World shall believe it: Nay, thou shalt think so thy selfâ€”Only let me not think so.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: No, I'll die before Ill be your Whoreâ€”as well as I love you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Aside. A Woman, and Ignorant, may be honest, when 'tis out of Obstinacy and Contradictionâ€”But S'death it is but a may be, and upon scurvy Termsâ€”Well, farewell thenâ€”if I can get out of her sight I may get the better of my self.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Wellâ€”good buy. Turns and Weeps.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ha! Nay come, we'll kiss at parting kisses her by Heaven she kisses sweeter than Libertyâ€”I will Marry theeâ€”There thou hast don't, all my Resolve melted in that Kissâ€”one more.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: But when?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I'm impatient till it be done; I will not give my self liberty to think, left I should coolâ€”I will about a Licence streightâ€”in the Evening expect meâ€”One Kiss more to confirm me mad; so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, an old Fox traptâ€”
Enter Lucy. Bless me! you frighted me, I thought he had been come again, and had heard me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, I met your Lover in as much haste, as if he had been going for a Midwife.

sp.speaker: Silo.
sp.p: He's going for a Parson, Girl, the forerunner of a Midwife, some nine Months henceâ€”Well, I find dissembling, to our Sex is as natural as swimming to a Negro; we may depend upon our skill to save us at a plunge, though till then we never make the experimentâ€”But how hast thou succeeded?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: As you would wishâ€”Since there is no reclaiming Vainlove, I have found out a picque she has taken at him; and have fram'd a Letter, that makes her sue for Reconciliation sust. I know that will doâ€”walk in and I'le shew it you. Come Madam, your like to have a happy time on't, both your Love and Anger satisfied! â€”All that can charm our Sex conspire to please you.
sp.l: That Woman sure enjoys a blessed Night,
Whom Love and Vengeance do at once delight.

div.head: SCENE I. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Bellmour in Fanatick habit, Setter..

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: T'Is pretty near the Hourâ€” Looking on his Watch. Well and how Setter hae, does my Hypocrisy sit me hae? Does it sit easy on me?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: O most religiously well Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wonder why all our young Fellows should glory in an opinion of Atheism; when they may be so much more conveniently lew'd, under the Coverlet of Religion.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: S'bud Sir, away quickly, there's Fondlewife just turn'd the Corner, and's coming this way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Gads so there he is, he must not see me. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: I say I will tarry at home.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: But Sir.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good lack! I profess the Spirit of contradiction hath possess'd the Ladâ€”I say I will tarry at homeâ€”Valet.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I have done Sir, then farewell 500 Pound.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Ha, how's that? Stay stay, did you leave word say you with his Wife? With Comfort her self.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I did; and Comfort will send Tribulation hither as soon as ever he comes homeâ€”I could have brought young Mr. Prig, to have kept my Mistress Company in the mean time: but you say.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How how, say Varlet! I say let him not come near my Doors. I say, he is a wanton young Levite and pampereth himself up with Dainties, that he may look lovely in the Eyes of Womenâ€”Sincerely I am afraid he hath already defiled the Tabernacle of our Sister Comfort; while her good Husband is deluded by his Godly appearanceâ€”I say, that even Lust doth sparkle in his Eyes, and glow upon his Cheeks, and that I would as soon trust my Wife, with a Lords high-fed Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir, the Howr draus nighâ€”And nothing will be done there till you come.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: And nothing can be done here till I goâ€”So that I'le tarry, d'ee see.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And run the hazard to lose your affair so!

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good lack, good lackâ€”I profess it is a very sufficient vexation, for a Man to have a handsome Wife.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Never Sir, but when the Man is an insufficient Husband. 'Tis then indeed, like the vanity of taking a fine House, and yet be forced to let Lodgings, to help pay the Rent.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: I profess a very apt Comparison, Varlet. Go in and bid my Cocky come out to me, I will give her some instructions, I will reason with her before I go. Exit Barnaby. And in the mean time, I will reason with my selfâ€” Tell me Isaac, why art th' Jealous? Why art thee distrustful of the Wife of thy Bosom ?â€”Because she is young and vigorous, and I am Old and impotentâ€”Then why didst thee marry Isaac?â€”Because she was beautiful and temping, and because I was obstinate and doating; so that my inclination was (and is still) greater than my powerâ€”And will not that which tempted thee, also tempt others, who will tempt her Isaac?â€”I fear it much â€”But does not thy Wife love thee, nay doat upon thee? â€”Yesâ€”Why then!â€”Ay, but to say truth, She's fonder of me, than she has reason to be; and in the way of Trade, we still suspect the smoothest Dealers of the deepest designsâ€”And that she has some designs deeper than thou canst reach, th' hast experimented Isaacâ€”But Mum.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: I hope my dearest Jewel, is not going to leave me. Are you Nykin?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Wifeâ€”Have you throughly consider'd how detestable, how halnous, and how Crying a Sin, the Sin of Adultery is? have you weigh'd it I say? For it is a very weighty Sin; and although it may lie heavy upon thee, yet thy Husband must also bear his part: For thy iniquity will fall upon his Head.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Bless me, what means my Dear!

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Aside I profess she has an alluring Eye; I am doubtfull, whether I shall trust her, even with Tribulation himselfâ€”Speak I say, have you consider'd, what it is to Cuckold your Husband?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Aside I'me; amaz'd sure he has discover'd nothingâ€”Who has wrong'd me to my Dearest? I hope my Jewel does not think, that ever I had any such thing in my Head, or ever will have.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: No no, I tell you I shall have it in my Headâ€”You will have it some where else.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Aside I know not what to think. But i'me resolv'd to find the meaning of itâ€”Unkind Dear! Was if for this, you sent to call me? is it not affliction enough that you are to leave me, but you must study to encrease it by unjust suspicions? Crying. Wellâ€”Wellâ€”You know my Fondness, and you love to Tyrannizeâ€”Go on cruel Man, do, Tritumph over my poor Heart, while it holds; which cannot be long, with this usage of yoursâ€”But that's what you wantâ€”Wellâ€”You will have your ends soonâ€”You willâ€”You willâ€”Yes it will break to oblige you. Sighs.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Verily I fear I have carry'd the Jest, too farâ€”Nay look you now if she does not weepâ€”'tis the fondest Foolâ€”Nay Cocky Cocky, nay dear Cocky, don't cry, I was but in Jest, I was not ifeck.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Aside Oh then alls safe, I was terrible frightedâ€”My affliction is always your Jest, barbarous Man! Oh that I should love to this degree! yet.â€”

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Nay Cocky.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: No no, you are weary of me, that's itâ€”That's all, you would get another Wifeâ€”Another fond Fool, to break her Heartâ€”Well, be as cruel as you can to me, I'le pray for you; and when I am dead with grief, may you have one that will love you as well as I have done: I shall be contented to lie at peace in my cold Graveâ€”Since it will please you. Sighs.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good lack, good lack, she would melt a Heart of Oakâ€”I profess I can hold no longerâ€”Nay dear Cockyâ€”Ifeck you'l break my Heart â€”Ifeck you willâ€”See you have made me weepâ€”made poor Nykin weepâ€”Nay come Kiss, buss poor Nykinâ€”And I wont leave thee â€”Ile lose all first.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Aside How! Heav'n forbid! that will be carrying the Jest too far indeed.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Wont you Kiss Nykin?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Go naughty Nykin, you don't love me.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Kiss kiss, ifeck I do.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: No you dont. She Kisses him

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: What not love Cocky!

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Noâ€”h Sighs.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: I profess I do love thee better, than 500 Poundâ€”And so thou shalt say, for I'le leave it to stay with thee.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p:
No you shan't neglect your business for meâ€”No indeed you sane.
Nykinâ€”if you don't go, I'le think you been dealons of me still.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: He, he, he, wilt thou poor Fool? Then I will go, I wont be dealousâ€”Poor Cocky, Kiss Nykin, Kiss Nykin, ee, ee, ee,â€”Here will be the good Man anon, to talk to Cocky and teach her how a Wife ought to behave her self.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Aside I hope to have one that will shew me how a Husband ought to behave himselfâ€”I shall be glad to learn, to please my Jewel. Kiss.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: That's my good Dearâ€”Come Kiss Nykin once, more and then get you inâ€”Soâ€”Get you in, get you in, By, by.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: By Nykin.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: By Cocky.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: By Nykin. She goes in.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: By Cocky, by, by. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How! Araminta lost!

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: To confirm what I have said read this Gives a letter.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Reads Hum humâ€”And what then appear'd a fault, upon restection, seems only an effect of a too powerful passion. I'me afraid I give too grant a Proof of my own at this timeâ€”I am in disorder for what I have written. But something, I know not what, forced me. I only beg a favourable Censure of this and your, (Araminta.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Lost! Pray Heaven thou hast not lost thy Wits. Here, here, she's thy own Man, sign'd and seal'd tooâ€”To her Manâ€”A delicious Mellon pure and consenting ripe, and only waits thy Cutting upâ€”She has been breeding Love to thee all this while, and just now she is deliver'd of it.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: 'Tis an untimely Fruit, and she has miscarried of her Love.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Never leave this damn'd illnatur'd whimsey Frank? Thou hast a sickly peevish Appetite; only chew Love and cannot digest it.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Yes, when I feed my selfâ€”But I hate to be cram'dâ€”By Heav'n there's not a Woman, will give a Man the pleasure of a chase: My sport is always balkt or cut shortâ€”I stumble ore the Game I would pursue.â€”'Tis dull and unnatural to have a Hare run full in the Hounds Mouth; and would distaste the keenest Hunterâ€”I would have overtaken, not have met my Game.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: However I hope you don't mean to forsake it, that will be but a kind of a Mungril Curs trick. Well, are you for the Mall?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: No, she will be there this eveningâ€”Yes I will go tooâ€”And she shall see her error inâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: In her choice I gadâ€”But thou canst not be so great a Brute as to slight her.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: I should disappoint her if I did notâ€”By her management I should think she expects it.
sp.l: All Naturally fly what does pursue:
'Tis sit Men should be coy, when Women wooe.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Chamber in Fondle-wife's House.
div.stage: A Servant introducing Bellmour in Fanatick Habit, with a Patch upon one Eye, and a Book in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Here's a Chair, Sir if you please to repose your self. I'll call my Mistress.
Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Secure in my Disguise, I have out-fac'd Suspicion, and even dar'd Discovery.â€” This Cloak my Sanctity, and trusty Scarron's Novels my PrayerBook.â€” Methinks I am the very Picture of Montufar in the Hypocrites.â€”Oh! she comes.

q.l: So breaks Aurora through the Veil of Night;
Thus fly the Clouds, divided by her Light,
And ev'ry Eye receives a new-born Sight.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Thus strew'd with Blushes, likeâ€” Ah! Heav'n defend me! Who's this? Discovering him, starts.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Lover.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Vain-love's Friend! I know his Face, and he has betrayed me to him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are surprised. Did you not expect a Lover, Madam? Those Eyes shone kindly on my first Appearance, tho' now they are o'er-cast.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: I may well be surpriz'd at your Person and Impudence; they are both new to me.â€” You are not what your first Appearance promised: The Piety of your Habit was welcome, but not the Hypocrisie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Rather the Hypocrisie was welcome, but not the Hypocrite. Aside.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir? You have mistaken the House sure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have Directions in my Pocket, which agree with every thing but your Unkindness. Pulls out the Letter.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: My Letter! Base Vain-love! Then 'tis too late to dissemble. Aside. 'Tis plain then you have mistaken the Person. Going.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If we part so I'm mistaken.â€” Hold, hold, Madam;â€” I confess I have run into an Errour:â€” I beg your Pardon a thousand times.â€” What an eternal Block-head am I! Can you forgive me the Disorder I have put you into;â€” But it is a Mistake which any Body might have made.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: What can this mean! 'Tis impossible he should be mistaken after all this.â€” A handsom Fellow if he had not surpriz'd me: Methinks, now I look on him again, I would not have him mistaken. Aside. We are all liable to Mistakes, Sir: If you own it to be so, there needs no farther Apology.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Nay, 'Faith, Madam, 'tis a pleasant one, and worth your hearing. Expecting a Friend, last Night, at his Lodgings, till 'twas late; my Intimacy with him gave me the Freedom of his Bed: He not coming home all
Night, a Letter was deliver'd to me by a Servant, in the Morning: Upon the Perusal I found the Contents so charming, that you'd think of nothing all Day but putting 'em in practice.â€” 'till just now, (the first time I ever look'd upon the Superscription,) I am the most surpriz'd in the World to find it directed to Mr. Vain-love. Gad, Madam, I ask you a Million of Pardons, and will make you any Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: I am discover'd:â€” And either Vain-love is not guilty, or he has handsomly excused him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You appear concern'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: I hope you are a Gentleman;â€” and since you are privy to a weak Woman's Failing, won't turn it to the prejudice of her Reputation.â€”You look as if you had more Honour.â€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And more Love; or my Face is a False-Witness, and deserves to be pillory'd.â€” No, By Heaven, I swearâ€”

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Nay, don't swear if you'd have me believe you; but promise.â€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, I promise. â€” A Promise is so cold:â€” Give me leave to swearâ€” by those Eyes, those killing Eyes; by those healing Lips.â€”Oh! press the soft Charm close to mine,â€” and seal 'em up for ever.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Upon that Condition. He kisses her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Eternity was in that Moment.â€” One more, upon any Condition.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Nay, now.â€” I never saw any thing so agreeably Impudent. Aside. Won't you censure me for this, now;â€” but 'tis to buy your Silence. Kiss. Oh, but what am I doing!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Doing! No Tongue can express it,â€” not thy own; nor any thing, but thy Lips. I am faint with the Excess of Bliss:â€” Oh, for Love-sake, lead me any whither, where I may lie down;â€” quickly, for I'm afraid I shall have a Fit.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Bless me! What Fit?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, a Convulsion.â€” I feel the Symptoms.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Does it hold you long? I'm afraid to carry you into my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, No: Let me lie down upon the Bed;â€” the Fit will be soon over. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE changes to St. James's Park.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Lard, my Dear! I am glad I have met you:â€” I have been at the Exchange since, and am so tir'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Why, What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Oh the most inhumane, barbarous Hackney-Coach! I am jolted to a Jelly.â€” Am I not horridly touz'd? Pulls out a Pocket-Glass.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Your Head's a little out of Order.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p:
A little! O frightful! What a furious Fiz I have! O most rueful! Ha, ha, ha: O Gad, I hope no-body will come this Way, till I put my self
a little in Repair.â€” Ah! my Dear,â€” I have seen such unknown Creatures since,â€” Ha, ha, ha, I can't for my Soul help thinking that I look just like one of 'em:â€” Good Dear, pin this, and I'll tell you.â€” Very well.â€”So, thank you my Dear.â€” But as I was telling youâ€” Pish, this is the untoward'st Lockâ€” So, as I was telling youâ€” How d'ye like me now? Hideous, ha? Frightful still? Or how?

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: No, no; you're very well as can be.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: And soâ€” But where did I leave off, my Dear? I was telling youâ€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: You were about to tell me something, Child,â€” but you left off before you began.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Oh; a most Comical Sight: A Country-Squire, with the Equipage of a Wife and two Daughters, came to Mrs. Snipwel's Shop while I was there.â€” But, Oh Gad! Two such unlick'd Cubs!â€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I warrant, plump, Cherry-cheek'd Country-Girls.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Ay, O my Conscience; fat as Barn-door-Fowl: But so bedeck'd, you won't have taken 'em for Friezland-Hens, with their Feathers growing the wrong way.â€” O such Out-landish Creatures! Such Tramontanae, and Foreigners to the Fashion, or any thing in practice! I had not patience to behold.â€” I undertook the modelling of one of their Fronts, the more modern Structure.â€”

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Bless me, Cousin! Why wou'd you affront any body so? They might be Gentlewomen of a very good Family.â€”

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Of a very ancient one, I dare swear, by their Dress.â€” Affront! Plhaw, how you're mistaken! The poor Creature, I warrant, was as full of Courtesies, as if I had been her Godmother: The Truth on't is, I did endeavour to make her look like a Christian,â€” and she was sensible of it; for she thank'd me, and gave me two Apples, piping hot, out of her UnderPetticoat-Pocket,â€” Ha, ha, ha: And t'other did so stare and gape,â€”I fansied her like the Front of her Father's Hall; her Eyes were the two JutWindows, and her Mouth the great Door, most hospitably kept open, for the Entertainment of travelling Flies.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: So then; you have been diverted. What did they buy?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Why, the Father bought a Powder-Horn, and an Almanack, and a Comb-Case; the Mother, a great Fruz-Towr, and a Fat-Amber-Necklace; the Daughters only tore two Pair of Kid-Gloves, with trying 'em on.â€”Oh Gad, here comes the Fool that din'd at my Lady Free-love's t'other Day.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: May be he may not know us again.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: We'll put on our Masks to secure his Ignorance. They put on their Masks.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p:
Nay, gad, I'll pick up; I'm resolv'd to make a Night on't.â€” I'll go to Alderman Fondle-wise by-and, by, and get 50 Pieces more from him. Adslidikins, Bully, we'll wallow in Wine and Women. Why, this same Madera. Wine has made me as light as a Grashopper.â€” Hist, hist, Bally, dost thou
see those Tearers? Sings. Look you what here is,â€” Look you what here is:â€”Tollâ€”lollâ€”deraâ€”tollâ€”loll.â€” A-Gad, t'other Glass of Madera, and I durst have attack'd em in my own proper Person, without your help.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Come on then, Knight.â€” But d'ye know what to say to 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Say: Pooh, Pox, I've enough to say,â€” never fear it; â€” that is, if I can but think on't: Truth is, I have but a treacherous Memory.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O frightful! Cousin, What shall we do? These things come toward us.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: No matter,â€” I see Vain-love coming this way,â€” and, to confess my Failing, I am willing to give him an Opportunity of making his Peace with me;â€” and to rid me of these Coxcombs, when I seem oppress'd with 'em, will be a fair one.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Ladies, by these Hilts you are well met.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: We are afraid not.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p:
What says my pretty little Knapsack-Carrier?
To Belinda.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O monstrous filthy Fellow! Good slovenly Captain Huffe, Bluffe, (What's your hideous Name?) be gone: You stink of Brandy and Tobacco, most Soldier-like. Foh. Spits.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Now am I slap-dash down in the Mouth, and have not one Word to say. Aside.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I hope my Fool has not Confidence enough to be troublesom. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Hem! Pray Madam, Which Way's the Wind?

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: A pithy Questionâ€” Have you sent your Wits for a Venture, Sir, that you enquire?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Nay, now I'm inâ€” I can prattle like a Magpye. Aside.

div.stage: Enter Sharper and Vain-love, at a Distance.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Dear Araminta, I'm tir'd.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: 'Tis but pulling off our Masques, and obliging Vain-love to know us, I'll be rid of my Fool by fair means â€” Well, Sir Joseph, you shall see my Face. â€” But, be gone immediately. â€” I see one that will be Jealous, to find me in discourse with you. â€” Be discreet. â€” No reply; but away. Vnmasques.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: The great Fortune, that dined at my Lady Free-loves! Sir Ioseph, thou art a Mad-man. Agad, I'm in Love, up to the Ears. But I'll be discreet, and husht. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Nay, by the World, I'll see your face.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: You shall. Vnmasques.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ladies, your humble Servant.â€”We were afraid, you would not have given us leave to know you.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: We thought to have been private.â€”But we find fools, have the same advantage, over a Face in a Masque; that a Coward has, while the Sword is in the Scabbard.â€” So were forced to draw, in our own defence.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p:
My Blood rises at that Fellow: I can't stay where he is; and I must not draw in the Park.
To Sir Jos.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: I wish I durst stay to let her know my Lodging.â€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: There is in true Beauty, as in Courage, somewhat, which narrow Souls cannot dare to admire.â€”And see, the Owls are sled, as at the break of Day.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Very courtly.â€”I believe, Mr. Vain-love has not rubb'd his Eyes, since break of Day neither, he looks as if he durst not approach.â€”Nay, come Cousin, be friends with him.â€” I swear, he looks so very simply, ha, ha, ha.â€” Well, a Lover in the state of separation from his Mistriss, is like a Body without a Soul. Mr. Vain-love, shall I be bound for your good Behaviour for the future?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Now must I pretend ignorance equal to hers, of what she knows as well as I. Aside. Men are apt to offend ('tis true) where they find most Goodness to forgive.â€”But, Madam, I hope I shall prove of a Temper, not to abuse Mercy, by committing new Offences.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: So cold! Aside.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: I have broke the ice for you, Mr. Vain-love, and so I leave you. Come, Mr. Sharper, you and I will take a turn, and laugh at the Vulgar.â€”Both the great Vulgar and the small.â€”Oh Gad! I have a great Passion. for Cowley.â€”Don't you admire him?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Oh Madam! He was our English Horace.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p:
Ah so fine! So extreamly fine! So every thing in the World that I like.â€”Oh Lord, walk this way.â€” I see a couple, I'll give you their History.
Ex. Bel. and Sharp.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: I find, Madam, the Formality of the Law must be observ'd, tho' the Penalty of it be dispens'd with; and an Offender must Plead to his Arraignment, tho' he have his Pardon in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: I'm amaz'd! This Insolence exceeds the t'other;â€” whoever has encourag'd you to this assuranceâ€” presuming upon the easiness of my Temper, has much deceiv'd you, and so you shall find.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Hey day! Which way now? Here's fine doubling. Aside.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Base Man! Was it not enough to affront me with your sawcy Passion?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: You have given that Passion a much kinder Epithet than Sawcy, in another place.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Another place! Some villainous Design to blast my Honour.â€”But tho' thou hadst all the Treachery and Malice of thy Sex, thou canst not lay a Blemish on my Fame.â€” No, I have not err'd in one favourable Thought of Mankind.â€”How time might have deceiv'd me in you; I know not; my Opinion was but young, and your early baseness has prevented its growing to a wrong Belief.â€” Unworthy, and ungrateful! Be gone, and never see me more.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Did I dream? Or do I dream? Shall I believe my Eyes, or Ears? The Vision is here still.â€”Your Passion, Madam, will admit of no farther reasoning.â€”But here is a silent Witness of your acquaintance.â€”

div.stage: Takes out the Letter, and offers it: She snatches it, and throws it away.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: There's poison in every thing you touch.â€”Blisters will followâ€”

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: That Tongue, which denies what the Hands have done.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Still mystically, senceless and impudent.â€”I find I must leave the place.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'm gone. â€”She knows her Name's to it, which she will be unwilling to expose to the Censure of the first finder. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p:
Woman's Obstinacy made me blind to what Woman's Curiosity now tempts me to see.
Takes up the Letter, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Nay, we have spared No-body, I swear Mr. ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ pure Man; Where did you get this excellent Talent of Railingâ–ª

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, the Talent was born with me:â€” I confess, ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ taken care to improve it; to qualify me for the society of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Nay, sure Railing is the best qualification in a Woman's Mat â€¢â€¢

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: The second-best;â€” indeed I think. Enter Footman

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: How now, Pace? Where's my Cousin?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: She's not very well, Madam, and has sent to know, if your Ladiship would have the Coach come again for you?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O Lord, No, I'll go along with her. Come, Mr. Sharper.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Chamber in Fondle-wife's House.
div.stage: Enter Laetitia and Bellmour, his Cloak, Hat, &c. lying loose about the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here's no body, nor no noise;â€” 'twas nothing but your fears.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: I durst have sworn, I had heard my Monster's Voice.â€”I swear, I was heartily frightned.â€” Feel how my heart beats.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis an alarm to Love.â€” Come in again, and let usâ€”

div.p: Cocky, Cocky, Where are you, Cocky? I'm come home.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Ah! There he is. Make haste, gather up your things.

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Cocky, Cocky, open the door.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fox choak him, would his Horns were in his Throat. My Patch, my Patch. Looking about, and gathering up his things.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: My Jewel, Art thou there? No matter for your Patch.â€”You s'an't tum in, Nykin.â€” Run into my Chamber, quickly, quickly. You s'an't tum in. Bell. goes in.

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, Dear, Iseck I'm in haste.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Then, I'll let you in. Opens the Door.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Kiss, Dear,â€” I met the Master of the Ship by the way,â€” and I must have my Papers of Accounts out of your Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh, I'm undone! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Pray, first let me have 50 Pounds, good Alderman, for I'm in huste.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: A Hundred has already been paid, by your Order. Fifty? I have the Summ ready in Gold, in my Closet. Goes into his Close.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Agad, it's a curious, fine, pretty Rogue; I'll speak to her,â€”Pray, Madam, what News d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Sir, I seldom stir abroad. Walks about in disorder.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: I wonder at that, Madam, for 'tis most curious fine Weather.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Methinks, 't has been very ill Weather.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: As you say, Madam, 'tis pretty bad Weather, and has been so a great while.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Here are fifty Pieces in this Purse, Sir Iosephâ€”If you will tarry a Moment, till I fetch my Papers, I'll wait upon you down stairs.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p:
Ruin'd, past redemption! What shall I do?â€” Ha! This fool may be of use. Aside. Stand off, rude Russian. Help me, my Dear,â€”O bless me! Why will you leave me alone with such a Satyr?
As Fondl. is going into the Chamber, she runs to Sir Jos. almost pushes him down, and Cries out.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Bless us! What's the matter? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Your back was no sooner turn'd, but like a Lion, he came open mouth'd upon me, and would have ravished a kiss from me by main force.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: O Lord! Oh terrible! Ha, ha, ha, Is your Wife mad, Alderman?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh! I am sick with the fright; won't you take him out of my sight?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Oh Traytor! I'm astonished. Oh bloody-minded Traytor!

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Hey-day! Traytor your self.â€”By the Lord-Harry, I was in most danger of being ravish'd, if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Oh, how the blasphemous Wretch swears! Out of my house, thou Son of the Whore of Babylon; Off-spring of Bell and the Dragon.â€”Bless us! Ravish my Wife! My Dinah! Oh Schechemite! Begone, I say.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Why, the Devil's in the People, I think. Exit.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh! Won't you follow, and see him out of Doors, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: I'll shut this door, to secure him from coming back.â€” Give me the Key of your Cabinet, Cocky.â€”Ravish my Wife before my face! I warrant he's a Papist in his heart, at least, if not a French-man.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: What can I do now! Aside. Oh! my Dear, I have been in such a fright, that I forgot to tell you, poor Mr. Spin-text, has asad Fit of the Cholick, and is forced to lie down upon our bed.â€” You'll disturb him; I can tread softlier.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Alack poor Man.â€”No, no,â€”you don't know the Papers.â€”I won't disturb him; Give me the Key.

div.stage: She gives him the Key, goes to the Chamber-door, and speaks aloud.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: 'Tis no body but Mr. Fondlewife, Mr. Spin-text, lie still on your Stomach; lying on your Stomach, will ease you of the Cholick.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Ay, ay, lie still, lie still; don't let me disturb you. Goes in.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Sure, when he does not see his face, he won't discover him. Dear Fortune, help me but this once, and I'll never run in thy debt again.â€”But this Opportunity is the Devil.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good lack! Good lack!â€”I profess, the poor Man is in great torment, he lies as flatâ€” Dear, you should heat a Trencher, or a Napkin.â€”Where's Deborah? Let her clap a warm thing to his Stomach, or chafe it with a warm-hand, rather than fail. What Book's this?

div.stage: Sees the Book that Bellmour forgot.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Mr. Spintext's Prayer-Book, Dear.â€” Pray Heav'n it be a Prayer-Book. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good Man! I warrant he dropp'd it on purpose, that you might take it up, and read some of the pious Ejaculations. Taking up the Book. O bless me! O monstrous! A Prayer-Book? Ay, this is the Devil's Pater-noster. Hold, letme see; The Innocent Adultery.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Misfortune! Now all's ruin'd again. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Damn'd Chance! If I had gone a-Whoring with the Practice of Piety in my Pocket, I had never been discover'd.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Adultery, and innocent! O Lord! Here's Doctrine! Ay, here's Discipline!

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Dear Husband, I'm amaz'd:â€” Sure it's a good Book, and only tends to the Speculation of Sin.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Speculation! No, no; something went farther than Speculation when I was not to be let in.â€” Where is this Apocryphal Elder? I'll ferret him.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: I'm so distracted, I can't think of a Lye. Aside

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Come out here, thou Ananias incarnate.â€”Who, how now! Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Ha! Shrieks, as surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Oh, thou salacious Woman! Am I then brutified? Ay, I feel it here; I sprout, I bud, I blossom, I am ripe-horn-mad. But who, in the Devil's name, are you? Mercy on me for swearing. Butâ€”

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh, Goodness keep us! Who's this? Who are you? What are you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Soh.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: In the Name of theâ€” Oh! Good, my Dear, don't come near it I'm afraid 'tis the Devil; indeed it has hoofs, Deare.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Indeed, and I have Horns, Deare. The Devil, no, I'm afraid, 'tis the Flesh, thou Harlot. Deare, with the Pox. Come Syren, speak, confess, who is this reverend, brawny Pastor?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Indeed, and indeed, now my dear Nykenâ€” I never saw this wicked Man before.

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Oh, it is a Man then, it seems.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Rather, sure it is a Wolf in the cloathing of a Sheep.

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Thou art a Devil in his proper Cloathing, Womans-flesh. What, you know nothing of him, but his Fleece here!â€” You don't love Mutton?â€”you Magdalen unconverted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, now I know my Cue.â€” That is very honourably, to excuse her, and very impudently accuse my self. Aside.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Why then, I wish I may never enter into the Heaven of your Embraces again, my Dear, if ever I saw his face before.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: O Lord! O strange! I am in admiration of your impudence. Look at him a little better; he is more modest, I warrant you, than to deny it. Come, Were you two never face to face before? Speak.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Since all Artisice is vainâ€”and I think my self obliged to speak the truth in justice to your Wife.â€”No.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Humph.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: No, indeed Dear.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Nay, I find you are both in a Story; that, I must confess. But, whatâ€”not to be cured of the Cholick? Don't you know your Patient, Mrs. Quack? Oh, lie upon your Stomach; lying upon your Stomach will cure you of the Cholick. Ah! I wish he has lain upon no-bodies stomach but his own. Answer me that, Jezabel?

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Let the wicked Man answer for himself; does he think that I have nothing to do but excuse him; 'tis enough, if I can clear my own innocence to my own Deare.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By my troth, and so 'tis.â€”I have been a little too backward, that's the truth on't. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Come, Sir, Who are you, in the first place? And what are you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Whore-master.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Very Concise.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: O beastly, impudent Creature.

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Well Sir, And what came you hither for?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To lie with your Wife.

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Good againâ€”A very civil Person this, and, I believe speaks truth.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh, insupportable Impudence!

sp.speaker: Fondl.
sp.p: Well, Sir,â€”Pray be cover'dâ€”and you haveâ€”Heh! You have finish'd the matter, Heh? And I am, as I should be, a sort of a civil Perquisite to a Whore-master, called a Cuckold, Heh. Is it not so? Come, I'm inclining to believe every word you say.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, Faith I must confess, so I design'd you.â€”But, you were a little unlucky in coming so soon, and hindred the making of your own Fortune.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Humph. Nay, if you mince the matter once, and go back of your word; you are not the Person I took you for. Come, come, go on boldly â€”What, don't be asham'd of your Profession.â€”Confess, confess, I shall love thee the better for't.â€” I shall, Ifeckâ€” What, dost think I don't know how to behave my self in the Employment of a Cuckold, and have been 3 Years Apprentice to Matrimony? Come, come, plain-dealing is a Jewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, since I see thou art a good honest Fellow, I'll confess the whole matter to thee.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Oh, I am a very honest Fellowâ€”You never lay with an honester Man's Wise in your life.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: How my heart akes! All my comfort lies in his impudence, and Heaven be praised, he has a considerable Portion. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In short then, I was informed of the opportunity of your absence, by my Spy, (for Faith, honest Isaac, I have a long time designed thee this favour) I knew Spin-text was to come by your directionâ€”But I laid a trap for him, and procured his Habit; in which, I pais'd upon your Servants, and was conducted hither. I pretended a Fit of the Cholick, to excuse my lying down upon your Bed, hoping that when she heard of it, her good Nature would bring her to administer Remedies for my Distemper.â€” You know what might have follow'd.â€” But like an uncivil Person, you knock'd at the Door, before your Wife was come to me.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Ha! This is Apocryphal; I may chuse whether I will believe it or no.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That you may, Faith, and I hope you wou'd believe a word on't.â€”But I can't help telling the truth, for my life.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How! Would not you have me believe you, say you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, for then you must of consequence part with your Wife, and there will be some hopes of having her upon the Publick; then the encouragement of a separate maintenance.â€”

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: No, no, for that matterâ€”when she and I part, she'll carry her separate-maintenance about her.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Ah cruel Dear, how can you be so barbarous? You'll break my heart, if you talk of parting. Cries.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Ah, dissembling Vermin!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
How canst thou be so cruel, Isaac? Thou hast the Heart of a Mountain-Tyger. By the faith of a sincere Sinner, she's innocent, for me. Go to him, Madam, fling your snowy Arms about his stubborn Neck; bathe his relentless face in your salt trickling Tears.â€” So, a few soft Words, and a Kiss; and the good Man melts. See, how kind Nature works, and boils over in him.
She goes and hangs upon his neck, and kisses him. Bell, kisses her hand, behind Fondle-wife's back.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, I was but just coming down stair, when you knock'd at the door; and the Maid told me, Mr. Spin-text was ill of the Cholick, upon our bed. And won't you speak to me, cruel Nykin? Indeed, I'll die, if you don't.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Ah! No, no, I cannot speak; my heart's so fullâ€”I have been a tender Husband, a tender Yoke-fellow; you know I haveâ€”But thou hast been a faithless Dallilah, and the Philistines have been upon thee. Heh! Art thou not vile and unclean, Heh? Speak. Weeping.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: No-h. Sighing.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Oh, that I could believe thee!

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh, my heart will break! Seeming to faint.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Heh, How? No, stay, stay, I will believe thee, I will.â€” Pray, bend her forward, Sir.

sp.speaker: Laet.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Where is my â€¢â€¢ ar.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Here, here, I do believe thee.â€” I won't believe my own Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For my part, I am so charm'd with the Love of your Turtle to you, that I'll go and sollicite Matrimony with all my might and main.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Well, well, Sir, as long as I believe'st, 'tis well enough. No thanks to you Sir, for her Vertue.â€”But, I'll show you the way out of my house, if you please. Come, my Dear. Nay, I will believe thee, I do, Ifeck.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: See the great Blessing of an easy Faith; Opinion cannot err.
sp.l: No Husband, by his Wife, can be deceiv'd:
See still is Vertuous, if she's so believ'd.

div.head: SCENE I. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Bellmour in Fanatick Habit, and Setter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: SEtter! Well encounter'd.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Joy of your Return, Sir. Have you made a good Voyage? Or have you brought your own Lading back?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, I have brought nothing but Ballast back,â€” made a delicious Voyage, Setter; and might have rode at Anchor in the Port till this time, but the Enemy surpriz'd us.â€” I wou'd unrig.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I attend you, Sir.

div.stage: Heart-well and Lucy appear at Sylvia's Door.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Ha! Is not that Heartwell at Sylvia's Door; be gone quickly, I'll follow you:â€” I wou'd not be known.
Exit Setter. Pox take 'em, they stand just in my Way.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I'm impatient till it be done.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That may be, without troubling your self to go again for your Brother's Chaplain. Don't you see that stalking Form of Godliness?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: O Pox; He's a Fanatick.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: An Executioner qualified to do your Business. He has been lawfully ordain'd.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I'll pay him well, if you'll break the Matter to him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
I warrant you.â€” Do you go and prepare your Bride.
Ex. Heartw.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Humph, Sits the Wind there?â€” What a lucky Rogue am I! Oh, what Sport will be here, if I can persuade this Wench to Secresie!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir: Reverend Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Now, Goodness have Mercy upon me! Mr. Bellmour! Is it you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Evenâ€” What dost think?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Think: That I shou'd not believe my Eyes, and that you are not what you seem to be.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: True. But to convince thee who I am, thou know'st my old Token. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Bellmour: O Lard! I believe you are a Parson in good earnest, you kiss so devoutly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Your Business with me, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I had none, but through Mistake.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Which Mistake you must go thorough with, Lucy.â€”Come, I know the Intrigue between Heartwell and your Mistress; and you mistook me for Tribulation-Spin-text, to marry 'em.â€” Ha? Are not Matters in this posture?â€” Confess.â€” Come, I'll be faithful: I will I-faith.â€”What Diffide in me, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Alas-a-day! You and Mr. Vain-love, between you, have ruin'd my poor Mistress: You have made a Gap in her Reputation; And can you blame her if she stop it up with a Husband?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, It is as I say?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, It is then: But you'll be secret?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Phuh, Secret, ay.â€” And to be out of thy Debt, I'll trust thee with another Secret. Your Mistress must not marry Heartwell, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: How! O Lord!â€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Nay, don't be in Passion, Lucy:â€” I'll provide a fitter Husband for her.â€” Come, Here's Earnest of my good Intentions for thee too: Let this mollisie.â€” Gives her Money. Look you, Heartwell is my Friend; and
tho' he be blind, I must not see him fall into the Snare, and unwittingly marry a Whore.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Whore! I'd have you know, my Mistress scornsâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, nay: Look you, Lucy; there are Whores of as good Quality.â€” But to the purpose, if you will give me Leave to acquaint you with it.â€” Do you carry on the Mistake of me: I'll marry 'em.â€” Nay, don't pause:â€” If you do, I'll spoil all.â€”I have some private Reasons for what I do, which I'll tell you within.â€”In the mean time, I promise, â€” and rely upon me,â€” to help your Mistress to a Husband:â€” Nay, and thee too, Lucy,â€” Here's my Hand, I will; with a fresh Assurance. Gives her more Money.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ah, the Devil is not so cunning.â€” You know my easie Nature.â€” Well, For once I'll venture to serve you; but if you do deceive me, the Curse of all kind, tender-hearted Women light upon you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's as much as to say, The Pox take me.â€” Well lead on. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Just now, say you, gone in with Lucy?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I saw him, Sir; and stood at the Corner where you found me, and over-heard all they said. Mr. Bellmour is to marry 'em.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ha, ha; 'Twill be a pleasant Cheat.â€” I'll plague Heart-well when I see him. Prithee, Frank, let's teaze him; make him fret till he foam at the Mouth, and disgorge his Matrimonial Oath with Interest.â€”Come, thou'rt so musty.â€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Sir, A Word with you. Whispers him.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Sharper swears, she has forsworn the Letter.â€” I'm sure he tells me Truth;â€” but I am not sure she told him Truth:â€” Yet she was unaffectedly concern'd, he says; and often blush'd with Anger and Surprize:â€” And so I remember in the Park.â€” She had reason, if I wrong her.â€” I begin to doubt.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Say'st thou so!

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: This Afternoon, Sir, about an Hour before my Master received the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: In my Conscience, like enough.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Ay, I know her, Sir: At least, I'm sure I can fish it out of her. She's the very Sluce to her Lady's Secrets:â€” 'Tis but setting her Mill agoing, and I can drein, her of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Here, Frank; your Blood-Hound has made out the Fault: This Letter, that so sticks in thy Maw, is Counterfeit; only a Trick of Sylvia in Revenge; contriv'd by Lucy.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ha! It has a Colour.â€” But how do you know it, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I do suspect as much;â€” because why, Sir: â€” She was pumping me about how your Worship's Affairs stood towards Madam Araminta. As, When you had seen her last; When you were to see her next; And, Where you were to he found at that time: And such like.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: And where did you tell her?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: In the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: There I receiv'd the Letter.â€” It must be so.â€” And why did you not find me out, to tell me this before, Sot?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Sir, I was Pimping for Mr. Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: You were well employ'd.â€” I think there is no Objection to the Excuse.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Pox o' my sawcy Credulity.â€” If I have lost her, I deserve it. But if Confession and Repentance be of force, I'll win her, or weary her into a Forgiveness. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Methinks I long to see Bellmour come forth.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Talk of the Devilâ€” See where he comes.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Hugging himself in his prosperous Mischief.â€” No real Fanatick can look better pleas'd after a successful Sermon of Sedition.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sharper! Fortifie thy Spleen: Such a Jest! Speak when thou art ready.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Now, were I ill-natur'd, wou'd I utterly disappoint thy Mirth: Hear thee tell thy mighty Jest, with as much Gravity as a Bishop hears Venereal Causes in the Spiritual Court: Not so much as wrinkle my Face with one Smile; but let thee look simply, and laugh by thy self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pshaw, No: I have a better Opinion of thy Wit.â€” Gad, I desie thee.â€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Were it not Loss of Time, you should make the Experiment. But honest Setter, here, over-heard you with Lucy, and has told me all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, then I thank thee for not putting me out of Countenance. But, to tell you something you don't know.â€” I got an Opportunity (after I had marry'd 'em) of discovering the Cheat to Sylvia. She took it at first, as another Woman would the like Disappointment; but my Promise to make her Amends quickly with another Husband, somewhat pacify'd her.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: But how the Devil do you think to acquit your self of your Promise? Will you marry her your self?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have no such Intentions at present.â€” Prithee, wilt thou think a little for me? I am sure the ingenious Mr. Setter will assistâ€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll leave him with you, and go shift my Habit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Heh! Sure, Fortune has sent this Fool hither on purpose. Setter, stand close; seem not to observe 'em; and, Hark-ye. Whispers.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Fear him not,â€” I am prepar'd for him now; and he shall find he might have safer rous'd a sleeping Lion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Hush, hush: Don't you see him?

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Shew him to me. Where is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Nay, Don't speak so loud.â€” I don't jest, as I did a little while ago.â€” Look yonder.â€” A-gad, if he shou'd hear the Lion roar, he'd cudgel him into an Asa, and his primitive Braying. Don't you remember the Story' in AEsop's Fables, Bully? A-Gad there are good Morals to be pick'd out of AEsop's Fables, let me tell you that; and Reynard the Fox too.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Damn your Morals.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Prithee, don't speak so loud.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Damn your Morals: I must revenge th' Affront done to my Honour. In a low Voice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Ay; Do, do, Captain, if you think fit.â€” You may dispose of your own Flesh as you think sitting, d'ye see:â€” But, by the Lord Harry, I'll leave you. Stealing away upon his Tip-toes.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Prodigious! What, will you forsake your Friend in his extremity! You can't, in honour, refuse to carry him a Challenge.

div.stage: Almost whispering, and treading softly after him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Prithee, What do you see in my face, that looks as if I would carry a Challenge? Honour, is your Province Captain: Take itâ€” All the World know me to be a Knight, and a Man of Worship.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, I'm instructed.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Impossible! Araminta take a liking to a Fool! Aloud.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Her head runs on nothing else, nor she can talk of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I know, she commended him all the while we were in the Park; but I thought it had been only to make Vain-love jealous.â€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: How's this! Good Bully, hold your breath, and let's hearken. A-gad, this must be Iâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Death, it can't beâ€”An Oaf, an Ideot, a Wittal.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Ay, now it's out; 'tis I, my own individual Person.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: A Wretch, that has flown for shelter to the lowest shrub of Mankind, and seeks Protection from a blasted Coward.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: That's you, Bully. Back. Bluffe frowns upon Sir Ios!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: She has given Vain-love her Promise, to marry him before to Morrow Morning.â€” Has she not?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: She has, Sir;â€” And I have it in Charge to attend her all this Evening, in order to conduct her to the Place appointed.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, I'll go and inform your Master; and do you press her to make all the haste imaginable. Exit.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Were I a Rogue now, what a noble Prize could I dispose of! A goodly Pinnace, richly laden, and to launch forth under my Auspicious Convoy. Twelve Tousand Pounds, and all her Rigging; besides what lies conceal'd under Hatches.â€” Ha! All this committed to my Care!â€”Avaunt Temptation.â€” Setter, show thy self a Person of Worth; be true to thy Trust, and be reputed honest. Reputed honest! Hum: Is that all? Ay: For, to be honest is nothing; the Reputation of it is all. Reputation! What have such poor Rogues as I to do with Reputation?â€”'Tis above us:â€” And, for Men of Quality, they are above it. So that Reputation is e'en as foolish as Honesty.â€” And, for my part, if I meet Sir Ioseph with a Purse of Gold in his Hand, I'll dispose of mine to the best Advantage.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Heh, heh, heh: Here 'tis for you, i'Faith, Mr. Setter. Nay, I'll take you at your Word. Chinking a Purse.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Sir Ioseph and the Captain too! undone, undone! I'm undone, my Master's undone, my Lady's undone, and all the Business is undone.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: No, no, Never fear, Man, the Lady's business shall be done. Whatâ€”Come, Mr. Setter, I have over-heard all, and to speak, is but loss of time; but if there be occasion, let these worthy Gentlemen intercede for me. Gives him Gold.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, What d'ye mean? Corrupt my honesty.â€”They have indeed, very perswading faces. Butâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: 'Tis too little, there's more, Man. There, take allâ€”Nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Well, Sir Ioseph, you have such a winning way with you.â€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: And how, and how, good Setter, did the little Rogue look, when she talk'd of Sir Ioseph? Did not her Eyes twinkle, and her Mouth water? Did not she pull up her little Bubbies? Andâ€”A-gad, I'm so over-joy'dâ€”And stroke down her Belly; and then step aside to tie her Garter, when she was thinking of her Love. Heh, Setter.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Oh, Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: How now, Bully? What, melancholy because I'm in the Ladies favours?â€”No matter, I'll make your peace.â€”I know, they were a little smart upon youâ€”But, I warrant, I'll bring you into the Ladies good Graces.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Pshaw, I have Petitions to show, from other-guess-toys than she. Look here: These were sent me this Morningâ€”There, read. Shows Letters. Thatâ€”That's a Scrawl of Quality. Here, here's from a Countess too. Humâ€”No holdâ€”That's from a Knight's Wife, she sent it me by her Husbandâ€”But here, both these are from Persons of great Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p:
They are either from Persons of great Quality, or no Quality at all, 'tis such a Damn'd ugly Hand.
While Sir Ioseph reads, Bluffe whispers Setter.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Captain, I wou'd do any thing to serve you; but this is so difficult.â€”

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: Not at all. Don't I know him?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: You'll remember the Conditions?â€”

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: I'll give't you under my Hand.â€” In the mean time, here's Earnest. Gives him Money. Come, Knight;â€” I'm capitulating with Mr. Setter for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Ah, honest Setter.â€” Sirrah, I'll give thee any thing but a Night's Lodging. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Nay, Prithee, leave Railing, and come along with me: May be she mayn't be within. 'Tis but to yond' Corner-house.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Whither? Whither? Which Corner-House?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Why, there: The Two white Posts.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And who wou'd you visit there, say you? (O'ons, How my Heart akes.)

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Pshaw; Thou'rt so troublesom and inquisitive.â€” Why, I'll tell you: 'Tis a young Creature that Vain-love debauch'd, and has forsaken. Did you never hear Bellmour chide him about Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Death, and Hell, and Marriage! My Wife! Aside.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Why, thou art as musty as a New-married Man, that had found his Wife Knowing the first Night.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Hell, and the Devil! Does he know it? But, hold:â€”If he shou'd not, I were a Fool to discover it.â€” I'll dissemble, and try him. Aside. â€”Ha, ha, ha. Why, Tom; Is that such an Occasion of Melancholy? Is it such an uncommon Mischief?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: No, Faith; I believe not.â€” Few Women, but have their Year of Probation, before they are cloister'd in the narrow Joys of Wedlock. But prithee come along with me, or I'll go and have the Lady to my self. B'w'y' George. Going.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: O Torture! How he racks and tears me!â€” Death! Shall I own my Shame, or wittingly let him go and whore my Wife? No, That's insupportable.â€” Oh, Sharper.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Oh, I am-married.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: (Now hold Spleen.) Married!

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Certainly, irrecoverably married.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid, Man. How long?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Oh, an Age, an Age: I have been married these two Hours.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: My old Batchelor married! That were a Jest. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Death: D'ye mock me? Heark-ye: If either you esteem my Friendship, or your own Safety,â€” come not near that House,â€” that Corner-house,â€” that hot Brothel. Ask no Questions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Mad, by this Light.
sp.l: Thus Grief still treads upon the Heels of Pleasure:
Marry'd in haste, we may repent at leisure.

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Some by Exprience find those Words misplac'd: At leisure marry'd, they repent in haste. As I suppose my Master Heartwell.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Here again, my Mercury!

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Sublimate, if you please, Sir! I think my Atchievments do deserve the Epithet.â€” Mercury was a Pimp too; but, tho' I blush to own it at this time, I must confess I am somewhat fall'n from the Dignity of my Function; and do condescend to be scandalously employ'd in the Promotion of Vulgar Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: As how, dear dexterous Pimp?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Why, to be brief, for I have weighty Affairs depending:â€”Our Stratagem succeeding as you intended,â€” Bluffe turns errand Traytor; bribes me to make a private Conveyance of the Lady to him, and put a Shain-Settlement upon Sir Ioseph.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: O Rogue! Well, but I hopeâ€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: No, no; never fear me, Sir.â€” I privately inform'd the Knight of the Treachery; who has agreed, seemingly to be cheated, that the Captain may be so in reality.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Where's the Bride?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Shifting Cloaths for the purpose at a Friend's House of mine. Here's Company coming, if you'll walk this way, Sir, I'll tell you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bellmour, Belinda, Araminta and Vain-love.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p:
Oh, 'twas Frenzy all: Cannot you forgive it?â€” Men in Madness have a Title to your Pity.
To Araminta.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: â€” Which they forfeit when they are restor'd to their Senses.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: I am not presuming beyond a Pardon.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: You who cou'd reproach me with one Counterfeit, how insolent wou'd a real Pardon make you? But there's no need to forgive what is not worth my Anger.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p:
O my Conscience, I cou'd find in my Heart to marry thee, purely to be rid of thee.â€” At least, Thou art so troublesome a Lover, there's Hopes thou'lt make a more than ordinary quiet Husband.
To Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Say you so?â€” Is that a Maxim among ye?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Yes: You flattering Men of the Mode have made Marriage a mere French Dish.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope there's no French Sawce. Aside.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: You are so curious in the Preparation, that is, your Courtship, one wou'd think you meant a noble Entertainment:â€” But when we come to feed, 'tis all Froth, and poor, but in show. Nay, often, only Remains, which have been I know not how many times warm'd for other Company, and at last serv'd up cold to the Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That were a miserable Wretch indeed, who cou'd not afford one warm Dish for the Wife of his Bosom.â€” But you timorous Virgins, form a dreadful Chimaera of a Husband, as of a Creature contrary to that soft, humble, pliant, easie thing, a Lover, so guess at Plagues in Matrimony, in Opposition to the Pleasures of Courtship. Alas! Courtship to Marriage, is but as the Musick in the Play-house, till the Curtain's drawn; but that once up, then opens the Scene of Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Oh, foh,â€” no: Rather, Courtship to Marriage, as a very witty Prologue to a very dull Play.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Hist,â€” Bellmour: If you'll bring the Ladies, make haste to Silvia's Lodgings, before Heartwell has fretted himself out of breath.â€” I'm in haste now, but I'll come in at the Catastrophe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
You have an Opportunity now, Madam, to revenge your self upon Heartwell, for affronting your Squirrel.
To Belinda.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: O the filthy rude Beast!

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: 'Tis a lasting Quarrel: I think he has never been at our House since.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But give your selves the trouble to walk to that CornerHouse, and I'll tell you by the way what may divert and surprize you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Gone forth, say you, with her Maid!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: There was a Man too that fetch'd 'em out:â€” Setter, I think they call'd him.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p:
So-h,â€” That precious Pimp tooâ€” Damn'd, damn'd Strumpet! Cou'd she not contain her self on her Wedding-Day! Not hold out till Night! Leave me.
Exit Boy.
O cursed State! How wide we err, when apprehensive of the Load of Life!
sp.l: â€”We hope to find
That Help which Nature meant in Woman-kind,
To Man that Supplemental-Self design'd;
But proves a burning Caustick when apply'd.
And Adam, sure, cou'd with more Ease abide
The Bone when broken, than when made a Bride.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now George, What Rhyming! I thought the Chimes of Verse were past, when once the doleful Marriage-knell was rung.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Shame and Confusion. I am exposed.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Joy, Joy Mr. Bride-groom; I give you Joy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: 'Tis not in thy Nature to give me Joy.â€”A Woman can as soon give Immortality.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, O Gad, Men grow such Clowns when they are married.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That they are fit for no Company but their Wives.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Nor for them neither, in a little timeâ€”. I swear, at the Month's End, you shall hardly find a Married-man, that will do a civil thing to his Wife, or say a civil thing to any body else. Iesu! how he looks already. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Death, Am I made your Laughing-stock? For you, Sir, I shall find a time, but take off your Wasp here, or the Clown may grow boistrous, I have a Fly-flap.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: You have occasion for't, your Wife has been blown upon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's home.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Not Fiends or Furies could have added to my vexation, or any thing, but another Woman.â€”You've wrack'd my patience; begon, or Byâ€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold. What the Devil, thou wilt not draw upon a Woman?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Bless me! What have you done to him?

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Only touch'd a gall'd-beast till he winch'd.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Bellmour, Give it over; you vex him too much; 'tis all serious to him.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Nay, I swear, I begin to pity him, my self.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p:
Damn your pity.â€” But let me be calm a little.â€” How have I deserv'd this of you? Any of ye? Sir, have I impair'd the Honour of your House, promis'd your Sister Marriage, and whor'd her? Wherein have I injured you? Did I bring a Physician to your Father when he lay expiring, and endeavour to prolong his life, and you One-and-twenty? Madam, have I
had an Opportunity with you and bauk'd it? Did you ever offer me the Favour that I refus'd it? Orâ€”

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Oh foh! What does the filthy-fellow mean? Lard, let me begone.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: Hang me, if I pity you; you are right enough serv'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a little scurrilous tho'.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a Sore of your own scratching.â€”Well George,â€”

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: You are the principal Cause of all my present Ills. If Sylvia had not been your Whore, my Wife might have been honest.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: And if Sylvia had not been your Wife, my Whore might have been just.â€”There, we are even.â€”But have a good heart, I heard of your Misfortune, and come to your relief.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: When Execution's over, you offer a Reprieve.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: What would you give?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Oh! Any thing, every thing, a Leg or two, or an Arm; nay, I would be divorced from my Virility, to be divorced from my Wife.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Faith, that's a sure way.â€”But here's one can sell you freedom better cheap.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Vain-love, I have been a kind of a God-father to you, yonder. I have promised and vow'd some things in your Name, which I think you are bound to perform.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: No signing to a Blank, friend.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: No, I'll deal fairly with you.â€”'Tis a full and free Discharge to: Sir Ioseph, Wittal and Captain Bluffe; for all Injuries whatsoever, done unto you by them; until the present Date hereof.â€”How say you?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Then, let me beg these Ladies to wear their Masques, a Moment.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What the Devil's all this to me.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Patience.
Re-enter Sharper, with Sir Ioseph, Bluffe, Sylvia, Lucy, Setter.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: All Injuries whatsoever, Mr. Sharper.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Ay, ay, whatsoever, Captain, stick to that, whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: 'Tis done, those Gentlemen are witnesses to the general Release.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay, ay, to this instant Moment.â€”I have past an Act of Oblivion.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: 'Tis very generous, Sir, since I needs must ownâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: No, no, Captain, you need not own, Heh, heh, heh. 'Tis I must ownâ€”

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p:
â€”That you are over-reach'd too, ha, ha, ha, only a little Art military, usedâ€”only undermined, or so, as shall appear by the
fair Araminta, my Wive's permission. Oh, the Devil, cheated at last! Lucy unmasques.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Only a little Art-military Trick, Captain, only countermin'd, or soâ€”Mr. Vain-love, I suppose you know whom I have gotâ€”now, but all's forgiven.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: I know whom you have not got; pray Ladies convince him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Ah! O Lord, my heart akes.â€” Ah! Setter, a Rogue of all sides.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Sir Ioseph, you had better have pre-engag'd this Gentleman's Pardon: For though Vain-love be so generous to forgive the loss of his Mistress.â€”I know not how Heart-well may take the loss of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: My Wife! By this Light 'tis she, the very Cockatriceâ€”Oh Sharper! Let me embrace thee.â€”But art thou sure she is really married to him?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: Really and lawfully married, I am witness.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Bellmour will unriddle to you. Heart-well goes to Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, Who are you? For I find, you and I are like to be bitter acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.p: The worst of me, is, that I am your Wifeâ€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Come, Sir Ioseph, your Fortune is not so bad as you fear.â€”A fine Lady, and a Lady of very good Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.p: Thanks to my Knight-hood, she's a Ladyâ€”

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: â€”That deserves a Fool with a better Title.â€”Pray use her as my Relation, or you shall hear on't.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: What, Are you a Woman of Quality too, Spouse?

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: And my Relation; pray let her be respected accordingly.â€”Well, honest Lucy, Fare-thee-well.â€”I think, you and I have been Play-fellows off-and-on, any time this Seven Years.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Hold your prating.â€”I'm thinking what Vocation I shall follow, while my Spouse is planting Laurels in the Wars.

sp.speaker: Bluffe.
sp.p: No more Wars, Spouse, no more Wars.â€”While I plant Laurels for my Head abroad, I may find the Branches sprout at home.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Bellmour, I approve thy mirth, and thank thee.â€”And I cannot in gratitude (for I see which way thou art going) see thee fall into the same snare, out of which thou hast deliver'd me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I thank thee, George, for thy good intention.â€”But there is a fatality in Marriage.â€”For I find I'm resolute.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Then good Councel will be thrown away upon you.â€”For my part, I have once escap'dâ€”And when I wed again, may she beâ€”Ugly, as an old Bawd.â€”.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: â€” Ill-natur'd, as an old Maid.â€”

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wanton, as a Young-widow.â€”

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And jealous as a barren Wife.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well; 'Midst of these dreadful Denunciations, and notwithstanding the Warning and Example before me, I commit my self to lasting Durance.

sp.speaker: Belin.
sp.p: Prisoner, make much of your Fetters: Giving her Hand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Frank, Will you keep us in Countenance.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p:
May I presume to hope so great a Blessing?
To Araminta.

sp.speaker: Aram.
sp.p: We had better take the Advantage of a little of our Friends Experience first.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O my Conscience she dares not consent, for fear he shou'd recant. Aside. Well, we shall have your Company to Church in the Morning?â€” May be it may get you an Appetite to see us fall to before ye. Setter, Did not you tell me?â€”

sp.speaker: Setter.
sp.p: They're at the Door: I'll call 'em in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now set we forward on a Journey for Life:â€” Come, take your Fellow-Travellers. Old George, I'm sorry to see thee still plod on alone.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.l: With gawdy Plumes and gingling Bells made proud,
The youthful Beast sets forth, and neighs aloud.
A Morning-Sun his Tinsell'd Harness gilds,
And the first Stage a Down-hill Green-sword yields.
But, Oh,â€”
What rugged Ways attend the Noon of Life!
(Our Sun declines,) and with what anxious Strife,
What Pain we tug that galling Load, a Wife.
All Coursers the first Heat with Vigour run;
But 'tis with Whip and Spur the Race is won. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: AS a rash Girl, who will all Hazards run,
And be enjoy'd, tho' sure to be undone;
Soon as her Curiosity is over,
Would give the World she could her Toy recover:
So fares it with our Poet; and I'm sent
To tell you, he already does repent:
Would you were all as forward, to keep Lent.
Now the Deed's done, the Giddy-thing has leasure
' â€¢ o think oth' Sting, that's in the tail of Pleasure.
Methinks I hear him in Consideration!
What will the World say? Where's my Reputation?
Now that's at stakesâ€”No fool, 'tis out o'fashion.
If loss of that should follow want of Wit,
How many Vndone Men were in the Pit!
Why that's some Comfort, to an Author's fears,
If he's an Ass, he will be Try'd by's Peers.
But holdâ€”I am exceeding my Commission;
My Business here, was humbly to petition:
But we're so us'd to Rail on these Occasions,
I could not help one tryal of your Patience:
For 'tis our way (you know) for fear o'th' worst,
To be before-hand still, and cry Fool first.
How say you, Sparks? How do you stand affected?
I swear, young Bays within, is so dejected.
I would grieve your hearts to see him; shall I call him?
But then you cruel Criticks would so maul him!
Yet, may be, you'll encourage a beginner;
But how?â€”Iust as the Devil does a Sinner.
Women and Wits, are used e'en much at one;
You gain your Ends, and damn 'em when you've done.
